headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Today's conference call will contain certain forward-looking statements, including those about our guidance and the financial position and operations of our tenants. These statements are made as of today's date and reflect the company
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Today's conference call will contain certain forward-looking statements, including those about our guidance and the financial position and operations of our tenants. These statements are made as of today's date and reflect the company's good-faith beliefs and best judgment based on current information. These statements are subject to the risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are described in our press releases and SEC filings, including our annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended 2015. 
Forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance. Actual results and financial condition may differ materially from those indicated in these forward-looking statements. Future events could render the forward-looking statements untrue, and the company expressly disclaims any obligation to update earlier statements as a result of new information.
Additionally, certain non-GAAP financial measures will be discussed on this call. We have provided reconciliations of these measures to the comparable GAAP measures in our supplemental information package and earnings release, both of which have been furnished to the SEC today and are available on our website at www.hcpi.com. Also during the call, we will discuss certain operating metrics, including occupancy, cash flow coverage and same property performance. These metrics and other related terms are defined in our supplemental information package.
I will now turn the call over to our CEO, Lauralee Martin.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John, and welcome to HCP's 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Joining me this morning are Tim Schoen, Chief Financial Officer; Justin Hutchens, Chief Investment Officer of Senior Housing and Care; and John Lu, EVP of Corporate Financ
componenttext:
Thank you, John, and welcome to HCP's 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Joining me this morning are Tim Schoen, Chief Financial Officer; Justin Hutchens, Chief Investment Officer of Senior Housing and Care; and John Lu, EVP of Corporate Finance and Investments. 
2015 was a very active year for us on almost every front, and we are proud of the performance we achieved in our operating portfolio. I will be covering these accomplishments later in the call, but I'd like to start with HCR ManorCare. As many of you are aware, the post-acute and skilled nursing industry has transformed remarkably over the past 5 years, beginning with the 2011 RUGs-IV cuts. The 3 most impactful trends have been: lower reimbursement rates, accelerated payer mix shift towards managed care and increased regulation and risk management requirements for patient care delivery. These changes have prompted operators to become more efficient while continuing to provide their quality care. Over the long term, these changes should ultimately benefit patients, payers and quality providers like HCR ManorCare, whose core operations have a high-quality mix and better margins compared to their peers. 
We are seeing heightened volatility in the public post-acute operators due to these industry-wide changes and headwinds. HCR is confronting the same challenges, which resulted in their normalized fixed charge coverage declining 4 basis points to 1.07x for calendar year 2015. Both we and HCR management were disappointed with HCR's results in the fourth quarter, which is typically a seasonally stronger quarter. These results were impacted by core operating performance weakness and $14 million of unfavorable nonroutine items, including short-term disruption related to the sales process of the 50 nonstrategic assets, 33 of which have closed to date with 17 still in process so some disruptions will continue into the first half of this year; as well as legal costs associated with the Department of Justice defense. 
For 2016, HCR anticipates normalized EBITDAR of $577 million before the temporary impact from the pending asset sales and Department of Justice defense costs. After adjusting for these items, HCP estimates 2016 EBITDAR to be $555 million, supporting their ability to meet the master lease obligations. Furthermore, we have applied sensitivities to key census assumptions in their forecast to produce a potential range of outcomes. Our forecast for HCR's 2016 EBITDAR ranges from $505 million to $555 million, resulting in a fixed charge coverage range of 1.06x to 1.16x. Our range includes the contractual -- current contractual rent and the 3% increase that goes into effect in April.
With the declining trend of operating performance in the second half of 2015, the DFL investment has been placed on cash basis effective January 1. In addition, given the lower growth outlook over the next few years, the carrying value of our HCR real estate portfolio was reduced by over $800 million to $5.2 billion as of year-end. Tim will cover the financial details shortly.
Our other objectives outlined in the April 2015 lease amendment are proceeding on track. We have received fee ownership in 7 of HCR's 9 recently built post-acute facilities, with the remaining to close by April, and we have sold 33 of the 50 properties, generating proceeds of $280 million. The remaining facilities are all under contract and scheduled to close over the next 2 quarters, which will bring total proceeds to $350 million.
Resolving the HCR ManorCare portfolio issue is our highest priority. Our goals in resolving the HCR ManorCare challenges are: reduce our concentration to HCR as an operator; improve the coverage and credit quality of our lease; and ensure HCR's high-quality care and service delivery continues. We have engaged Barclays Capital as our financial adviser to pursue discussions with HCR ManorCare's management team to jointly explore all solutions to achieve our goals.
Now let me turn the call over to Tim to discuss our financial results and 2016 guidance.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lauralee. Let me start with our fourth quarter results. For the quarter, we reported a NAREIT FFO loss of $0.99 per share, reflecting noncash impairments of $836 million related to our HCR ManorCare investments. The impairments reduced the ca
componenttext:
Thank you, Lauralee. Let me start with our fourth quarter results. For the quarter, we reported a NAREIT FFO loss of $0.99 per share, reflecting noncash impairments of $836 million related to our HCR ManorCare investments. 
The impairments reduced the carrying value of our HCR ManorCare DFL real estate portfolio from $6 billion to $5.2 billion at year-end, which approximates the fair value of the assets based on market-level coverage and cap rate assumptions. In addition, the carrying value of our 9% equity investment in opco was reduced by $19 million. Excluding the impact of impairments and other items totaling $1.79 per share for the quarter, we reported FFO as adjusted of $0.80 per share and FAD of $0.67 per share, representing growth rates of 1% and 2%, respectively, compared to the fourth quarter of 2014. The results benefited from accretive acquisitions closed in 2015.
Fourth quarter same-store cash NOI performance declined 30 basis points compared to prior year due to the HCR ManorCare lease amendment in April 2015. Excluding the HCR ManorCare portfolio, we achieved solid same-store cash NOI growth of 3.5%, led by a 7.8% increase in life science and a 6.6% increase in RIDEA, which Justin will cover in a few minutes. Also benefiting the quarter was a $0.01 per share gain from monetizing our senior housing development project in Olney, Maryland.
Turning to our full year 2015 results. We reported a full year 2015 NAREIT FFO loss of $0.02 per share that was primarily impacted by noncash impairments related to HCR ManorCare. Excluding the impact of impairments and other items, 2015 FFO as adjusted was $3.16 and FAD was $2.72 per share, representing year-over-year growth rates of 4% and 6%, respectively. The earnings performance, despite the amended HCR ManorCare lease, was driven by same-store cash NOI growth of 3.7% from 75% of our portfolio and accretive acquisitions totaling $4 billion since 2014. In addition, the results included a $0.04 of onetime gains from monetizing 3 senior housing development loans. 
Absent these gains, on a recurring basis, FFO as adjusted per share increased 3% and FAD increased 4% in 2015. Overall, same-store cash NOI for the year increased 50 basis points, consistent with our last guidance. Our 2015 cash dividend of $2.26 per share resulted in an FAD payout ratio of 83%.
Moving on to financing activities and balance sheet. In the fourth quarter, we raised $600 million of senior unsecured notes at a 4% coupon. Proceeds were used to refinance a $500 million bond maturity last week, representing 36% of our 2016 total maturities, and to pay down on the revolver. During 2015, we successfully raised $2.3 billion of debt at an attractive blended rate of 3.5%. 
We continued to deliver on the capital recycling front, generating $430 million of additional proceeds during the quarter, bringing our total for the year to $560 million. Proceeds for the quarter included $208 million from the sale of HCR ManorCare's nonstrategic assets, $110 million from creation of a new institutional JV on our Memorial Hermann MOB portfolio and $45 million from monetizing our interest in MOB Ventures III and IV. We improved our liquidity and financial leverage with these proceeds, although the benefit to financial leverage was offset by our fourth quarter noncash impairments. Leverage ended the year at 45%.
Fixed charge coverage and net debt to adjusted EBITDA for 2015 were 3.9x and 5.6x, respectively. Secured debt ratio improved to 4.4% as we continued to refinance higher-rate mortgage maturities with lower-cost unsecured notes. 
At year-end, we had $1.6 billion of liquidity.
Next, our full year 2016 guidance and dividend. The majority of our portfolio continues to generate organic growth, complemented by recent accretive investments, but our earnings continue to be moderated by the HCR ManorCare lease restructure as we enter 2016. Before providing our 2016 guidance, I would like to discuss a few important assumptions reflected in our projections that impact year-over-year comparison. 
First, beginning January 2016, income from our HCR ManorCare investments will be recognized on a cash basis, resulting in a reduction to our FFO run rate totaling $150 million or $0.32 per share, $90 million of which was previously recognized in DFL revenue, with the remaining $60 million in equity income from unconsolidated joint ventures. There is no impact to our cash performance metrics, including same-store and FAD. Our 2016 guidance reflects contractual rent of $456 million from our HCR ManorCare real estate portfolio, inclusive of a scheduled 3% increase in April.  In addition, our guidance reflects $130 million of proceeds in the first half of 2016, bringing total proceeds from HCR ManorCare's nonstrategic asset sales to $350 million.
Second, you will recall that as part of our 2014 Brookdale transaction, Brookdale agreed to pay $55 million of lease restructure payments and installments over a 3-year period as consideration to convert 49 assets from a triple-net lease to RIDEA. Starting in July 2016, the payments step down and will be phased out by the third quarter of 2017. Also, as part of this transaction, we have a rent reduction of $6.5 million this year in exchange for canceling 49 purchase options on Brookdale's triple-net portfolio.
Third, we entered into a purchase and sale agreement with Genentech, who exercised their purchase option on our life science campus in south San Francisco. The first tranche of the transaction will close in November for a price of $310 million and the second tranche closing in 2018 for $270 million. Proceeds will be reinvested to fund our development at The Cove in south San Francisco, including the recently commenced Phase 2.
Lastly, in 2016, we will continue to reflect our Four Seasons unsecured note on nonaccrual status, and we'll record interest payments received as a reduction to our investment. Our guidance does not include the impact of any future acquisitions or dispositions other than what I just mentioned. 
With these assumptions, we expect full year 2016 FFO to range from $2.74 to $2.80 per share, which reflects placing our HCR ManorCare portfolio on a cash basis; FAD to range from $2.62 to $2.68 per share; same-store cash NOI growth to increase between 1.5% and 2.5%; the remaining 75% of our portfolio, excluding HCR ManorCare, to increase between 2.3% and 3.3%.
The midpoint of our same-store growth rates by asset class include: senior housing at 1.75%, which is impacted by the Brookdale triple-net portfolio I just mentioned and reflects RIDEA growth of 3.5%. Post-acute SNF is forecasted to decline by 60 basis points due to the HCR ManorCare lease amendment in April 2015. In our operating office platform, life science is projected to grow 6.7% and MOB at 2.4%. And finally, our hospital segment is projected to grow 2.2%.
Allow me to quickly run through a few other assumptions. G&A is forecasted to be $87 million, including stock-based compensation of $20 million; amortization of below-market lease intangibles and deferred revenue of $4 million; amortization of deferred financing costs of $21 million; straight-line rents of $16 million; other depreciation and amortization of $12 million; lease restructure payments of $17 million related to the 2014 Brookdale transaction, reflecting a step down in the installment payments starting in the second half of 2016; our 49% share of FFO contribution from the CCRC joint venture to range from $28 million to $30 million; and FAD contribution to range from $45 million to $49 million, inclusive of nonrefundable interest fees; leasing costs and second-generation tenant and capital expenditures of $90 million, representing 5% of cash NOI; in addition, total development, redevelopment and first-generation capital investments of $410 million, including $150 million in 2016 for the completion of Phase 1 and commencement of Phase 2 life science development at The Cove in south San Francisco.
I'll conclude with a few words on our 2016 dividend. Last month, we increased our quarterly dividend from $0.565 to $0.575 per share, marking the 31st consecutive year of dividend increases and continuing HCP's representation in the S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrat Index. The annualized dividend of $2.30 represents an increase of $0.04 per share over 2015. 
After taking into account the increase in the dividend and based on the midpoint of our guidance, our projected 2016 payout ratio is in the mid-80% range. As a result, we expect to retain $165 million in cash flow after dividends and recurring capital expenditures to continue growing our portfolio.
With that summary of our financial results, I will now turn the call over to Justin. Justin?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tim. Let me start by highlighting our senior housing portfolio performance. Our total senior housing same-store cash NOI grew 3.7% in 2015, driven largely by rent steps and in part by our Brookdale RIDEA portfolio. We are encouraged by Brookd
componenttext:
Thank you, Tim. Let me start by highlighting our senior housing portfolio performance. 
Our total senior housing same-store cash NOI grew 3.7% in 2015, driven largely by rent steps and in part by our Brookdale RIDEA portfolio. We are encouraged by Brookdale's indication that their merger integration is in their rearview mirror and by the recent additions to their senior management team. These factors, along with a significant Program Max CapEx investment, have contributed to the recent improvement in growth in our RIDEA properties, and we expect them to have a positive impact on the triple-net portfolio. We are in regular communication with Brookdale management regarding ways to work together to create value through asset repositioning, operating and market analytics and identifying opportunities to cull the portfolio.
Our same-store RIDEA platform reported a very strong fourth quarter, with year-over-year same-store growth of 6.6%, driven by improved occupancy rate and expense management. We are encouraged by this performance and are particularly pleased to see positive momentum, where fourth quarter occupancy grew 60 basis points on a year-over-year basis and 70 basis points on a sequential basis, outperforming the NIC average by 90 basis points year-over-year and 60 basis points sequentially. The entire Brookdale RIDEA portfolio has performed consistent with these solid results.
Our triple-net senior housing portfolio has a trailing 12-month cash flow coverage of 1.07x, down 2 basis points from the prior quarter. The triple-net portfolio is largely represented by the leases with Brookdale, where the coverage in 2016 is expected to improve by 2 basis points due to a contractual rent reduction that was committed in conjunction with the 2014 transaction with Brookdale that Tim mentioned earlier. We remain actively engaged with our operators through our asset management platform, continuously reviewing local market dynamics, operating trends and the physical condition of our properties. 
We continue to monitor new supply in our senior housing markets and have included a new presentation of this information, which is featured on Page 27 of the supplemental. We measure new supply using a 5-mile radius based on a recent study showing that the average time a consumer is willing to travel to a local business is approximately 15 minutes. Our internal research indicates that a 5-mile analysis is generally consistent with that of a 15-minute drive time. 21.2% of our RIDEA NOI or 2.7% of our total portfolio income has new construction or expansions of similar care types within a 5-mile radius. A large majority of this new supply will open in 2016. We are mindful of the potential pressure on pricing and occupancy that the new supply could cause in these markets. However, we like our market position relative to the new higher-cost competitors.
Moving on to investments. During the fourth quarter, we expanded our relationship with Brookdale and MBK with $57 million of investments in 4 senior housing communities, all stabilized with occupancy above 90%. Our priority pipeline includes $400 million of senior housing communities with new and existing operator relationships. We plan to fund these investments from the capital recycling and the assumption of in-place debt. We are primarily focused on acquiring private-pay communities that offer both assisted living and memory care services and located in targeted markets with favorable supply-demand characteristics.
I would like to emphasize that we remain conservative and selective as we advance capital into senior housing assets. As part of our underwriting and due diligence process, we carefully scrutinize operators' track record, financial alignment and local-market industry fundamentals, including potential impact from wage pressures and new supply.
Now Lauralee will cover our medical office, life science and international portfolios.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Justin. As I opened, 2015 was a very active year for us on almost every front, and we are proud of the performance we have achieved despite operator challenges. In 2015, we sourced over $2 billion of accretive investments at a blended 6.8% cash
componenttext:
Thank you, Justin. As I opened, 2015 was a very active year for us on almost every front, and we are proud of the performance we have achieved despite operator challenges. In 2015, we sourced over $2 billion of accretive investments at a blended 6.8% cash yield across 4 of our property sectors, bringing our 2-year investment total to $4 billion at a blended 7.3%. These investments are performing at or above our underwriting, including our CCRC and Chartwell portfolios managed by Brookdale; our international investments with HC-One and Maria Mallaband; our medical office acquisitions of on-campus MOBs in Philadelphia and Houston; and our premier life science development, The Cove. 
We accomplished almost 90% of our 2015 growth through our existing partners, but we also added new high-quality relationships, including Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia, MBK Senior Living and several companies within our life science portfolio. We remain selective and disciplined in allocating capital, with 3/4 of our 2015 investments concentrated in private-pay senior housing and on-campus medical office buildings, and more than half of our investments were completed through joint venture partnerships, emphasizing our focus on mutual alignment. 
One common theme we have seen over the past year is strong increases in occupancy across our operating portfolios, supported by the location of our properties and their competitive position in their markets. We delivered occupancy growth in our RIDEA, life science and medical office portfolios.  Justin already covered RIDEA portfolio growth, so I will focus my comments on our office platform.
Our life science portfolio has had strong leasing momentum this year, driving occupancy to a new all-time high of over 98%, a 300 basis point improvement over prior year. We have now pre-leased half of our state-of-the-art development at The Cove with CytomX Therapeutics and Denali Therapeutics as lead tenants. CytomX will lease 76,000 square feet beginning in the fourth quarter. They recently had a successful IPO based on their cancer-fighting research. Denali will lease 38,000 square feet beginning in the third quarter. Led by former Genentech neuroscience leadership, Denali is a private company focused on neurodegenerative diseases and seeded with over $200 million, the largest first-round venture financing in biotech history. We are very pleased to welcome both CytomX and Denali as our first 2 clients at The Cove, and we look forward to continuing to build more relationships with innovative and growing companies like these. 
In response to our Phase 1 leasing success and continued strong demand from life science users in South San Francisco, where direct vacancy is still below 1%, we recently commenced the $185 million development of Phase 2, which will add 2 Class A buildings totaling up to 230,000 square feet and is expected to be delivered by the third quarter of 2017. We acquired Edgewater Science and Technology Park in south San Francisco for $83 million. The 6-building campus was recently renovated and is 100% occupied. 
Our medical office portfolio also had a solid year of leasing, with year-end occupancy close to 92%, representing 110 basis points of growth over the prior year, driven by our strong retention rates of 83% and recent acquisitions. We have expanded our MOB platform by over 20% over the past 2 years, primarily with on-campus buildings, while adding 11 new health system partners and expanding 2 existing relationships. We are partners with top-notch health systems in every regional area where we have a strong presence. For example, HCA, our largest relationship, has significant market share in 7 of our top 12 markets where we have at least 500,000 square feet of office space.
We won the trust of Memorial Hermann, a leading hospital system in Houston with a 24% market share, who selected us as their partner to execute the monetization of their on-campus MOB portfolio, and they continue to select HCP as a capital partner. In January, we broke ground on a 170,000 square foot development on the campus of Memorial Hermann's Woodlands hospital. The development is 100% pre-leased and represents our third on-campus development project underway with them. 
In total, we have 6 MOBs under development or redevelopment, totaling 760,000 square feet, of which 5 are expected to be completed during the first half of the year. Our MOB portfolio remains in great shape, with 40% of this year's lease expirations already addressed or in negotiations. We have achieved solid growth in our non-HCR ManorCare portfolio, which represents 3/4 of HCP's business. In conclusion, I would like to reiterate that solving the HCR ManorCare lease issue is our highest priority.
Operator, could you now open the line for questions.

I was hoping you could help us bridge the normalized EBITDAR forecast for HCR ManorCare from the $110 million in the fourth quarter or I guess, maybe $121 million, if you adjust for the losses on those 11 properties, on up to that $505 million to $555 million run rate. Because it would imply some pretty healthy EBITDAR growth at ManorCare. And it seemed perhaps optimistic, given the joint replacement bundling model that's going on and the bundled payments initiative, because there are some additional pressures coming across the industry.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Ross, going from the fourth quarter, there were some items, I'll start, that affected the fourth quarter. Both legal expenses and disruption or distractions from the asset sales, that -- probably in the $10 million to $15 million range suppressed the
componenttext: Yes. Ross, going from the fourth quarter, there were some items, I'll start, that affected the fourth quarter. Both legal expenses and disruption or distractions from the asset sales, that -- probably in the $10 million to $15 million range suppressed the fourth quarter. Then if you look at the first quarter, there's generally some seasonality and pickup in census, which we expect to happen. And HCR ManorCare has indicated that they've got a pickup in census here in January. So it's really census pickup and then some of the onetime items that they experienced in the fourth quarter.

componenttext: Well, first of all, their hospice business is #3 in terms of ranking, so it's a highly successful business. It's a business that they continue to grow. As you point out, we have the corporate guarantee over our lease, our master lease, and that is adding additional coverage to our performance on our lease. It is security for the entire bank group as well. So a valuable asset as to our lease and continues to be a successful part of HCR's business model.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the one other question I had was you mentioned hiring an adviser. It sounds like you're looking at a lot of options, one of which I'm wondering is if you were to sell a piece of the HCR real estate today. Realist  -- I mean you say you marked it
componenttext: And then the one other question I had was you mentioned hiring an adviser. Realist  -- I mean you say you marked it down to $5.2 billion, but let's assume that it would be difficult to maybe sell all that. Could you sell $1 billion of it? Could you sell $2 billion of it? What is -- who would buy it? What's the buyer pool like? And is that a plan that you're thinking about from hiring this adviser?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's premature to go into nuances, as you suggest. We've engaged Barclays. HCR is almost 25% of our portfolio, so incredibly important that we evaluate all options for our shareholders. And our goal is to reduce our concentration to HCR, improve the credi
componenttext: It's premature to go into nuances, as you suggest. We've engaged Barclays. HCR is almost 25% of our portfolio, so incredibly important that we evaluate all options for our shareholders. And our goal is to reduce our concentration to HCR, improve the credit quality of our lease, its coverage and the credit quality of our operator, and we will be doing that on behalf of shareholders for the best outcome.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess just a follow-up to that is -- you gave all the math sort of in the 10-K about the impairment and how you looked at valuation inputs. Do you realistically think that for a portfolio that there's a 1.35x rent coverage on the skilled nursing portfol
componenttext: I guess just a follow-up to that is -- you gave all the math sort of in the 10-K about the impairment and how you looked at valuation inputs. Do you realistically think that for a portfolio that there's a 1.35x rent coverage on the skilled nursing portfolio, you can get a sale done at an 8-something cap rate for $1 billion or $2 billion today, based on what's sort of gone on with the markets in the last 6 months?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Justin. Just to step back on the process we used, we obtained a third-party appraisal, and they took the approach of evaluating the properties from the highest invest-use standpoint. They used a market coverage ratio, as you mentioned. You might use
componenttext: It's Justin. Just to step back on the process we used, we obtained a third-party appraisal, and they took the approach of evaluating the properties from the highest invest-use standpoint. They used a market coverage ratio, as you mentioned. You might use a range of 1.25 to 1.35 for SNF, 1.05 to 1.15 for AL memory care; market lease rates, 7.5 to 8.5 for SNF, 6.25 to 7.25 for AL memory care. And from our perspective, there was some good market support for the ranges that they used.

componenttext: Okay. And just the last question on Brookdale, just to switch gears a little bit. I mean, how confident are you on kind of their coverage levels  improving from here? Is there a downside that you guys have looked at there that -- and anything you're thinking about to help maybe mitigate any downside risk there?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Justin. First of all, we share Andy's enthusiasm about his new management team. Labeed and Cindy offer a fresh perspective and a very relevant experience in their respective backgrounds. And elevating Mary Sue  Patchett, who has 25-plus year
componenttext: Sure. This is Justin. First of all, we share Andy's enthusiasm about his new management team. Labeed and Cindy offer a fresh perspective and a very relevant experience in their respective backgrounds. And elevating Mary Sue  Patchett, who has 25-plus years of senior housing operating experience, and marrying her with Labeed just seemed like a great fit. So we're impressed with the management team, and we're optimistic about their ability to carry out their plan. They've talked about putting a more efficient operating structure in place, have a community-level feedback loop that's going to help them to make decisions to simplify the business. They're tightening their use of incentives and going more shorter term than longer term in terms of price incentives. And the economies of scale that they have as the largest operator in the space should come into play, purchasing power and reducing insurance costs. And so if you look at our triple-net portfolio, it was impacted significantly after integration because you have largely legacy emeritus properties. Certainly, the integration is behind us. We do think that there'll be some new supply and wage pressure on the fringes that, that portfolio will face. From HCP's standpoint, we're enhancing our asset management. We're going to have a similar focus on our triple-net portfolio that we've had on our RIDEA portfolio, and one example of that would be to continue to work with Brookdale to deploy capital expenditures. There's about $50 million available for Brookdale to draw to invest in the triple-net portfolio. That'd be a significant investment of a few thousand dollars per unit. Certainly, we've proven that, that has impact in our RIDEA portfolio performance, so we would look for some similar results in the triple-net portfolio over time. Having said all of that, a lot of this is fresh. I know Brookdale's talked about using 2016 as a year to really put the business plan in place and take advantage of their ability to execute on all of the things I just mentioned. And so we're not expecting a big pop, by any means, in the triple-net portfolio, but we're optimistic that it'll be stable. And we'll look forward to seeing the results of their business plan over time.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I have to stay away from ManorCare now at this point. So could you just help us on 27, on the new slide with the new supply.How should we be sort of thinking about this from the new disclosure? What is that 2.7% now calculate? And then maybe, wh
componenttext:
I think I have to stay away from ManorCare now at this point. So could you just help us on 27, on the new slide with the new supply.
How should we be sort of thinking about this from the new disclosure? What is that 2.7% now calculate? And then maybe, what did that look like a year ago or just from sort of historical perspective?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Justin again. One point I think that is the key takeaway is the fact that really only about 2.7% of our NOI would be impacted by new supply. Having said that, most of that new supply is going to happen in 2016. And so the growth outlook we have in ou
componenttext: It's Justin again. One point I think that is the key takeaway is the fact that really only about 2.7% of our NOI would be impacted by new supply. Having said that, most of that new supply is going to happen in 2016. And so the growth outlook we have in our RIDEA platform at around 3.5% reflects some impact of new supply and on the fringe, some impact of wage pressure. I'll give you an example of how the new supply has impacted us. If you look at the last 2 years, we've had 18 openings within a 5-mile radius. And that's impacted actually to compare to that 2.7%, only about 1.3% of our portfolio income. You know from our RIDEA results that we moved growth rate through the impact. But I can tell you in those respective markets, we actually experienced flat occupancy, and then a very, very modest rate increase of about 50 basis points. So if the markets that we expect to have some impact in 2016, perform similar to our experience over the past 2 years. That reduces the growth outlook a little bit.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And when you say the potential NOI impact, you're saying it's somehow, you lost 100% of your NOI on a specific property, right? Like that's not an actual realistic view of what would normally happen, right? That's just absolute worst-case scenario. Is tha
componenttext: And when you say the potential NOI impact, you're saying it's somehow, you lost 100% of your NOI on a specific property, right? Like that's not an actual realistic view of what would normally happen, right? That's just absolute worst-case scenario. Is that right?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right. Rather than using number of units or number of communities, we wanted to use NOI as the number just to identify our concentration in the markets that have new supply. I'll give you another follow-up stat about in our -- specifically in our R
componenttext: That's right. Rather than using number of units or number of communities, we wanted to use NOI as the number just to identify our concentration in the markets that have new supply. I'll give you another follow-up stat about in our -- specifically in our RIDEA portfolio if you use their NOI, then you're around 20%. But whole company, you're down at 2.7%. But in any event, we've worked with Brookdale to factor in any impacts that we're going to experience in '16, and that's reflected in the outlook that Tim mentioned.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just last one for you, Justin. What would be like a normal growth, assuming you have some sort of supply coming in over the next couple of years, et cetera. But where do you think that sort of Brookdale RIDEA portfolio same-store cash NOI growth?
componenttext: And then just last one for you, Justin. What would be like a normal growth, assuming you have some sort of supply coming in over the next couple of years, et cetera. But where do you think that sort of Brookdale RIDEA portfolio same-store cash NOI growth? What is sort of a long-term growth rate for that?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, from our perspective when making the decision to invest the capital expenditures, we wanted to be sure that the result would be to outperform what a triple-net lease portfolio would give us, which would be about 3% growth. And so we're expecting 6%
componenttext: Well, from our perspective when making the decision to invest the capital expenditures, we wanted to be sure that the result would be to outperform what a triple-net lease portfolio would give us, which would be about 3% growth. And so we're expecting 6% growth and in fact, we're achieving that so far. So over time when we get into in markets where we are not impacted by new supply, we'd be looking to see around a 6% growth rate.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Kevin Tyler with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: The next question comes from Kevin Tyler with Green Street Advisors.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Going back to ManorCare for a second, so of the larger scale nursing operators, ManorCare certainly has one of the higher proportions of revenues coming from Medicare and probably Medicare Advantage. Is ManorCare doing anything proactively to shift the pa
componenttext: Going back to ManorCare for a second, so of the larger scale nursing operators, ManorCare certainly has one of the higher proportions of revenues coming from Medicare and probably Medicare Advantage. Is ManorCare doing anything proactively to shift the patient mix to be more Medicaid focused in light of the Medicaid Advantage headwinds?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Justin. Let me just step back a little bit on their business plan, and I'll talk about a number of things that relates to that question. If you step back to why they are where there are, I think it's important to look at this. Their senior managem
componenttext: This is Justin. Let me just step back a little bit on their business plan, and I'll talk about a number of things that relates to that question. If you step back to why they are where there are, I think it's important to look at this. Their senior management team has a tenure, and this is senior and divisional managers of over 20 years. And the business plan that they've executed over a 20-year period was to put themselves in position to be the market leader in terms of clinical and rehabilitation care and services. They've successfully done so. In the 11 market clusters where they operate, they are a leader in 9 of those. They're in second place in 2 of those. To your point, they achieved about a 66% percentage of their revenue, that's in Medicare and in managed care. And if you take that 66% number, it's about twice the industry average. So they're uniquely impacted by the shift to managed care and a reduced length of stay. And certainly, they've had to work through that. In some ways, they've done that. They have the hospice business that Lauralee mentioned earlier. They have an assisted living business that's been growing. They are looking in some other tertiary markets to dedicate some beds to a memory care program that would accept Medicaid reimbursement to help stabilize cash flow. But they do remain committed to their core business. And if you're interested in how that plays out in a mature managed care market, you can look at California. California is a state where they operate 7 properties and they have about 1,000 beds, so pretty good sample size. The length of stay in that portfolio is about 18% less than the rest of their company. They have only 40% of their admissions are coming from Medicare and 60% are managed care. So they would describe this as a mature managed care market. They actually grew admissions in California about 2.5% over this past year, and they grew operating income as well. So they found stability in the payer sources. They've been able to grow the business. And then I'd add another point to their core business. If you look at their business across the company, they've actually grown their admissions 1% a year, each of the last 4 years. So they are in fact, expanding market share. However, it has not been enough to overcome their reduced length of stay.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that extra level of detail, Justin. Shifting back to senior housing, on the call earlier today, Brookdale talked a bit about the returns that you've been receiving on the CapEx spend, both upfront and then, I guess, over time on the assets an
componenttext: I appreciate that extra level of detail, Justin. Shifting back to senior housing, on the call earlier today, Brookdale talked a bit about the returns that you've been receiving on the CapEx spend, both upfront and then, I guess, over time on the assets and the agreements that you have with them. But thinking about CapEx going forward and how you're allocating dollars for '16, is CapEx in the RIDEA portfolio largely accounted for at this point, given the money that you put in initially? Or how should we think about a number on a kind of a per-unit basis for '16?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on an aggregate portfolio basis, I had talked about in my prepared remarks, about $410 million in CapEx, $70 million of that would go into our RIDEA portfolios.
componenttext: Yes, on an aggregate portfolio basis, I had talked about in my prepared remarks, about $410 million in CapEx, $70 million of that would go into our RIDEA portfolios.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's split over the whole thing. Any more color I guess in terms of breaking that out specifically?
componenttext: And that's split over the whole thing. Any more color I guess in terms of breaking that out specifically?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll add a little color. There -- if you look at our spend in RIDEA portfolio, if you view the $1,500 per unit number from a routine spending standpoint, which is what we're allocating, we actually spent another $2,600 per unit in '14 and '15 on majo
componenttext: Yes. I'll add a little color. There -- if you look at our spend in RIDEA portfolio, if you view the $1,500 per unit number from a routine spending standpoint, which is what we're allocating, we actually spent another $2,600 per unit in '14 and '15 on major refreshes. Brookdale called us Program Max. In '16, we've actually allocated another $1,500 and we're -- but we're going to -- for routine, but we're going to spend $3,300 per unit in the major refreshes. So there is actually on a per-unit basis, some more major refresh capital being deployed this year. And then we do expect that into '17, getting closer to a normal run rate at that time.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned that you've hired advisers to help with your situation with HCR ManorCare. Do you know has HCR ManorCare and their owners, have they hired an adviser? And just given what looks like increasingly tight coverage, would you think they would con
componenttext: You mentioned that you've hired advisers to help with your situation with HCR ManorCare. Do you know has HCR ManorCare and their owners, have they hired an adviser? And just given what looks like increasingly tight coverage, would you think they would consider any kind of bankruptcy option at this juncture?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first, I can't comment on whether they've hired advisers or not, but let me go to bankruptcy. There's been no discussions of bankruptcy. Their forecast and the fixed charge coverage forecast that comes with that says that they can pay our lease and
componenttext: Well, first, I can't comment on whether they've hired advisers or not, but let me go to bankruptcy. There's been no discussions of bankruptcy. Their forecast and the fixed charge coverage forecast that comes with that says that they can pay our lease and their debt obligations and continue to invest the CapEx as appropriate. They also have $125 million of cash, and none of their debt matures for over 2 years. So we would believe it's very premature to be discussing bankruptcy.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: The other thing I just wanted to ask you, you recently made some changes in the company's bylaws that allow for easier shareholder proxy access. Was that in negotiation with investors? Or what was kind of the impetus for that change?

componenttext: Can you guys highlight what actually occurred in the second half of '15 that drove the weakness for HCR ManorCare? Was that largely driven by the temporary disruption mentioned in the prepared remarks? Or was there another core operating issue that occurred?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was part of it, but it was really the census in the shorter -- driven as a result of the shorter length of stay, Michael.
componenttext: That was part of it, but it was really the census in the shorter -- driven as a result of the shorter length of stay, Michael.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess what was the actual issue impacting the census? I mean, Medicare Advantage has been a problem right for the past, I guess, few years you kind of highlighted. Is there something specific that occurred that caused the census?
componenttext: I guess what was the actual issue impacting the census? I mean, Medicare Advantage has been a problem right for the past, I guess, few years you kind of highlighted. Is there something specific that occurred that caused the census?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you've got to increase -- you've got the mix shift that continues in the Medicare Advantage, which results in shorter length of stay. Actually, HCR ManorCare's admissions were up year-over-year, which they've done for the last several years. But the
componenttext: Well, you've got to increase -- you've got the mix shift that continues in the Medicare Advantage, which results in shorter length of stay. Actually, HCR ManorCare's admissions were up year-over-year, which they've done for the last several years. But the shift to Medicare Advantage has resulted in shorter length of stay, and that has a downward impact on census.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then what was the -- what's the drivers that you believe will cause census to go higher in 2016, right? Because that's what kind of pointed to why you think results will improve in 2016?
componenttext: And then what was the -- what's the drivers that you believe will cause census to go higher in 2016, right? Because that's what kind of pointed to why you think results will improve in 2016?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I mentioned, there were some onetime -- there were items -- non-core items in the fourth quarter called $15 million, that caused census to be low in the fourth quarter. Typically, the fourth quarter actually is a pretty strong quarter in terms of
componenttext: Yes, as I mentioned, there were some onetime -- there were items -- non-core items in the fourth quarter called $15 million, that caused census to be low in the fourth quarter. Typically, the fourth quarter actually is a pretty strong quarter in terms of census and it has been for the last several years. This year was a bit of an anomaly. So we would expect census and HCR started to see census increase into the first and second week of January and through January. So they had a good census rebound is what I would call it for the early part of the first quarter, more along historical averages.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: In reducing your exposure to ManorCare, is there a goal as to how much you'd like to decrease it to? And also is it correct to assume that you are considering asset sales and rent cuts? Or are there other options on the table?
componenttext: In reducing your exposure to ManorCare, is there a goal as to how much you'd like to decrease it to? And also is it correct to assume that you are considering asset sales and rent cuts? Or are there other options on the table?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's been no discussion of a rent cut. So what we've talked about is that we want to focus on reducing concentration, no defined level at this point in time, improving the credit quality of our lease and its coverage. And I think it's important that wh
componenttext: There's been no discussion of a rent cut. So what we've talked about is that we want to focus on reducing concentration, no defined level at this point in time, improving the credit quality of our lease and its coverage. And I think it's important that what we want to be doing is evaluating potential long-term solutions -- comprehensive solutions to make sure that we do the right thing for shareholders.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess you could either sell assets or part of the ManorCare portfolio or you could buy other assets to reduce your exposures. So is the second option on the cards as well?
componenttext: Sure. I guess you could either sell assets or part of the ManorCare portfolio or you could buy other assets to reduce your exposures. So is the second option on the cards as well?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's lots of solutions, all to be evaluated as we continue through this.
componenttext: There's lots of solutions, all to be evaluated as we continue through this.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you do go the asset sale route, it looks like your payout ratio would probably increase from where it is today. At what levels do you feel comfortable operating that payout before you consider a potential rental -- dividend cut?
componenttext: If you do go the asset sale route, it looks like your payout ratio would probably increase from where it is today. At what levels do you feel comfortable operating that payout before you consider a potential rental -- dividend cut?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we give you our dividend coverage ratios on the more conservative FAD basis. The company is run, up till about 2011 or 2012, into the high 90s. I mean, we could run at that level if we needed to, but we've got quite a bit of cushion. I mentioned we'v
componenttext: Yes, we give you our dividend coverage ratios on the more conservative FAD basis. The company is run, up till about 2011 or 2012, into the high 90s. I mean, we could run at that level if we needed to, but we've got quite a bit of cushion. I mentioned we've got $165 million in free cash flow after our dividend payout ratio today. So we've got quite a bit of cushion today and continue to have cushion in our dividend payout ratio.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: But in that sort of bearish [ph] case scenarios, did -- did that also consider asset sales?
componenttext: But in that sort of bearish [ph] case scenarios, did -- did that also consider asset sales?

componenttext: Well, John, that's where we're at today. We have $165 million in free cash flow today, and that equates to a mid-80% payout ratio. headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: Just to stick to ManorCare, you kind of alluded to that rent cut is not being considered right now. But I'm just sort of, if you go back to when the rent was cut, I'm just kind of wondering what sort of assumptions you had laid down at that point? Was this sort of envisioned as a more bare case scenario? And going back, do you think sort of a bigger rent cut would have probably been appropriate? Or would you -- were you also saying if there's a more bare scenario, we'll think of another rent cut down the road?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you remember at the time we did our lease amendment, we felt that we had done the right amount of rent concession for the pay-fors that we received from HCR; the 9 assets which obviously are very valuable. They are new postacute facilities. The deferre
componenttext: If you remember at the time we did our lease amendment, we felt that we had done the right amount of rent concession for the pay-fors that we received from HCR; the 9 assets which obviously are very valuable. They are new postacute facilities. The deferred lease obligation, which is ahead of Carlyle's and equity position. So we thought that was appropriate pay-fors and have no regrets about that decision. The situation today has really been as we've described. There is a significant decline, particularly in the fourth quarter end of year, that was not anticipated. And clearly, that's what's driven our decisions today.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just turning to -- on the RIDEA side, you sort of highlighted kind of the exposure and then some math around how supply is impacting it. I'm just wondering if we look over the next, say, year or 2, in the past, you've sort of said you'd like to grow the R
componenttext: Just turning to -- on the RIDEA side, you sort of highlighted kind of the exposure and then some math around how supply is impacting it. I'm just wondering if we look over the next, say, year or 2, in the past, you've sort of said you'd like to grow the RIDEA business. And correct me if I'm wrong, but I think today, you're somewhere in the low teens of the percent of NOI. In the past, you've sort of indicated you'd like to take that up maybe 15%, 20%. I'm wondering is that still the goal? Is that changed?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Justin. I just -- I want to qualify that we are very mindful -- we [indiscernible]  RIDEA platform, but we're very mindful that we're in an environment that has new supply, competitive pressures from new supply, wage pressure. So as we enter marke
componenttext: This is Justin. I just -- I want to qualify that we are very mindful -- we [indiscernible]  RIDEA platform, but we're very mindful that we're in an environment that has new supply, competitive pressures from new supply, wage pressure. So as we enter markets, we'll be very focused on underwriting local market fundamentals, the strength of the operators. When we consider structures, whether it's triple-net or RIDEA or other forms of a joint venture, we're always mindful of financial alignment to make sure that both parties are motivated to create value for the portfolio. So it's going to -- certainly be part of our growth plan, but we'll be very selective as we pursue operating risk in the near term.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just last one, Tim, for you, I know you've taken care of some of the maturities -- the debt maturities. Just wondering given all the -- the broader sort of concerns around whether it's CMBS or spreads widening in other parts of the capital struct
componenttext: And then just last one, Tim, for you, I know you've taken care of some of the maturities -- the debt maturities. Just wondering given all the -- the broader sort of concerns around whether it's CMBS or spreads widening in other parts of the capital structure, if you were to go to market today, what sort of pricing you think you could get? And could you maybe just update us on plans to tackle the remaining '16 and '17 maturities?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll take your comments in reverse order. In terms of the remaining maturities, I mentioned that we've got about $1.6 billion in liquidity underneath our line. We've also got $400 million in asset sales that are contractually in place today. So call
componenttext: Yes. I'll take your comments in reverse order. In terms of the remaining maturities, I mentioned that we've got about $1.6 billion in liquidity underneath our line. We've also got $400 million in asset sales that are contractually in place today. So call it $2 billion plus our free cash flow, so call it $2.1 billion, $2.2 billion. We've got left, Vikram, about $900 million in contractual debt maturities this year. So that sort of gives you the liquidity picture. And then in terms of the debt coming due, we've actually got an average coupon of anywhere from mid- to high 5s in the near term and into the low 6s as we look out into '17 and '18. So we've still got refinancing tailwind. And then finally, if we were to go to market today, obviously you followed the credit markets the last couple of weeks, you'd probably be in the mid-4 range on long-term 10-year debt -- 10-year unsecured debt.

componenttext: I'm trying to get my head a little more around the guidance, FFO guidance, Tim. Obviously, you put $3.16 in the current year. You're at $2.74 to $2.80 for -- excuse me, $3.16 last year, $2.74 to $2.80 for this year. You add the $0.32 back from the HCR ManorCare cash accrual issue and you're at $3.06 to $3.12. I'm trying to get where in essence the reduction is when you're assuming that you were going to have same-store FFO growth -- I mean same-store NOI growth of 2.3% to 3.3% excluding HCR ManorCare.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a couple of items John that affect the growth. There's -- our same-store growth should add about $0.08 to our run rate, but there's a number of items that we're going to anniversary. There's still the 1 quarter of the HCR ManorCare rent cut t
componenttext: Yes, there's a couple of items John that affect the growth. There's -- our same-store growth should add about $0.08 to our run rate, but there's a number of items that we're going to anniversary. There's still the 1 quarter of the HCR ManorCare rent cut that we have that affects the first quarter of '16. And then you've got the nonaccrual associated with the Four Seasons investment. And then in '15, we had $0.04 of onetime gains in our senior housing development platform. And then, as I mentioned as well, there was a Brookdale triple-net rent cut that paid for the cancellation of the 49 purchase options. And that was -- that's really the universe, and that adds up to about -- that offsets that $0.08 of growth and then some in the same store.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Justin. Our coverages are -- first of all, we don't have a lot of other concentration besides ManorCare in the SNF -- in our SNF business. But to the extent we do, the coverage ratios are good. And generally, as I mentioned earlier, most operators
componenttext: This is Justin. Our coverages are -- first of all, we don't have a lot of other concentration besides ManorCare in the SNF -- in our SNF business. But to the extent we do, the coverage ratios are good. And generally, as I mentioned earlier, most operators are less impacted. They're impacted as managed care penetrates markets and reduces length of stay and rate in the market. But ManorCare is more impacted because they're a market leader in that payer source. So any declines we've seen wouldn't have been as pronounced.

componenttext: Well, it was really the second half of the year, Jordan. You -- somebody asked a question in specifics what impacted the fourth quarter. Plus, I think, when you look at the continual mix shift that we've seen the last 4 or 5 years, we've seen continual industry headwinds, not only for HCR, but the postacute spacing. We think that's going to continue to exist.

componenttext: Well, listen, when we look at it, I think you can look at the sensitivities that we've provided in our disclosures today that represents a flat business plan in the SNF business at the high end and growth in hospice and AL. But at the lower end, it represents a continued census pressure from the mid-80s to the lower 80s, and then a flat growth in the AL and hospice business. So that's kind of what we've provided in our sensitivities for 2016.

componenttext: Yes, we're continuing to see the mix shift. And we continued to see that over the last 3 or 4 years, and that -- while the speed of the shift has declined, we continued to see the shift to Medicare Advantage and other managed plans. I don't see that's going to change.

componenttext: Well, I'll take the opco. The opco's been written down to 0. componenttext: Let me start by saying first of all, we used to have a 34% concentration to HCR, and we have now reduced it down below the 25%. headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: And then can you guys share some of the details from the third-party valuation for HCR ManorCare? Maybe just give us some metrics that whether it's cap rates, price per unit, anything, that would be helpful.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Justin. They use market coverage ratios for SNF from 1.25 to 1.35; for AL memory care, they use 1.05 to 1.15; market lease rates for SNFs 7.5 to 8.5, and for the AL memory care 6.25 to 7.25. So that gives you a range to consider, and that's
componenttext: Sure, this is Justin. They use market coverage ratios for SNF from 1.25 to 1.35; for AL memory care, they use 1.05 to 1.15; market lease rates for SNFs 7.5 to 8.5, and for the AL memory care 6.25 to 7.25. So that gives you a range to consider, and that's right in line with what the third-party appraisal used. And also they use the highest and best appraisal approach -- highest and best used appraisal approach.
