Thank you, Jamie. Today's conference call will contain certain forward-looking statements, including those about our guidance and the financial position and operations of our tenants. These statements are made as of today's date and reflect our good-faith beliefs and best judgment based on current information. These statements are subject to the risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are described in our press releases and SEC filings, including our annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended 2015.
Forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance. Actual results and financial condition may differ materially from those indicated in these forward-looking statements. Future events could render the forward-looking statements untrue, and the company expressly disclaims any obligation to update earlier statements as a result of new information.
Additionally, certain non-GAAP financial measures will be discussed on this call. We have provided reconciliations of these measures to the comparable GAAP measures in our supplemental information package and earnings release, both of which have been furnished to the SEC today and are available on our website at www.hcpi.com.
Also during the call, we will discuss certain operating metrics, including occupancy, cash flow coverage and same property performance. These metrics and other related terms are defined in our supplemental information package.
I will now turn the call over to our CEO, Mike McKee.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome, everyone. Joining me today is Justin Hutchens, our Chief Investment Officer; and John Lu, our Executive Vice President of Corporate Finance. And I'm pleased to welcome back Tom Herzog on his first earnings call since returning as our Chief Financ
componenttext:
Welcome, everyone. Joining me today is Justin Hutchens, our Chief Investment Officer; and John Lu, our Executive Vice President of Corporate Finance. And I'm pleased to welcome back Tom Herzog on his first earnings call since returning as our Chief Financial Officer.
We look forward to sharing with you our quarterly results and updates on several significant initiatives. But before diving into the details, I want to step back for several minutes and give you some additional color on the rationale behind some major changes at the company. They have a purpose.
I will start by saying this is an exciting time at HCP. It's a renaissance of sorts. I've been referring recently to the stage we are entering into as HCP 3.0. I've been fortunate to be a witness to and a participant in each of the generational periods of HCP since its formation in 1985.
The first generation was represented by our friend and founding CEO, Ken Roath. Well known to many of you, Ken established our company as one of the first healthcare REITs and grew it significantly with a solid foundation and a stellar reputation.
Jay Flaherty is identified with our second generation. Over his decade of leadership, he repositioned the company to a significant extent by moving away from properties reliant on government reimbursement and into larger transactions that provided scale as privatization and consolidation swept through the industry.
Lessons learned, one large transaction that we all take responsibility for was our purchase of HCR ManorCare in 2011. At the time of the purchase, this leading skilled nursing post-acute company was widely acclaimed as best in class, but it was also heavily reliant on government reimbursement. All of you know that over the last 5 years, the skilled nursing post-acute space has been rocked by numerous sequential challenges. The cumulative impact has been strongly felt across the sector.
When these issues came more into focus, we asked Lauralee Martin to take the helm and bridge us to the next generation. We knew we were giving her a tough hand to play, but none of us were able to predict how difficult the last few years would be as this space continued to be jolted by one decision or another imposed on it primarily by the payer shift toward Medicare Advantage and the net effect of sequestration cuts.
In the last few months, the board and I evaluated where we were and what the future could look like. In addition to the spin and the other initiatives in play, we determined that the best course was to move HCP 3.0 forward by starting to put the face on the team that would take the company forward into the next generation of evolution and growth.
With the initiatives we have announced and some we will announce shortly, all of us are confident and excited about our prospects for near- and longer-term performance and growth. I want to express my heartfelt appreciation for the effort and contribution that Lauralee gave us, getting us to the point that we can now launch this next stage.
Let me also report that the team that will take us forward is coming together very well. There is some blending of new folks in encore appearance and those that have been around for many years. They are working marvelously together, and I am confident that you will see tangible positive results soon from the groundwork that is underway.
In assembling this team, there is a method to our madness. It's been noted by many of you that we've added some key executives like Justin Hutchens and Kai Hsiao with strong reputations as leaders and operators of large healthcare companies. And we've added other new team members, who aren't as publicly visible with similar backgrounds.
Our long-tenured executives, Tom Klaritch and John Bergschneider, who run our medical office and life science platforms, are as well regarded as anyone in their respective roles. And with Tom Herzog returning to our team, we have someone widely regarded for his conservative yet progressive thinking around balance sheet, cost of capital management and strategic capital allocation. We'll stack this talented team up against any in the industry.
Now, looking ahead, one of the biggest questions we face like many REITs is how do you plan to grow going forward. Well, our assessment is that there is plenty of room to grow, but it will be a different strategic path than in recent -- in the recent past. Much of the growth in the future will come through affiliations with provider networks and picking experienced operators and partnering with them for growth.
The good news is that the healthcare real estate market remains large and in many areas, highly fragmented. HCP is being shaped to be the capital partner of choice because we understand the needs of the operator and we know how operations either succeed or fail. We believe that our ability to attract and underwrite potential investments will benefit from the internal resources assembled, and we believe we will quickly become a trusted partner to selected new operators and emerging provider networks because we talk their language and have an appreciation of their needs.
We understand business needs because we have run businesses and we have walked in our tenants' shoes. So when we talk about a new generation, HCP 3.0, we are talking not just about change but strategic change to meet the market where it is and where it's going.
With that said, there are some key overhangs that we are aggressively addressing to position us for growth. First, we are obviously addressing the issues related to HCR ManorCare with the spin transaction. Second, although we have a high degree of confidence in Brookdale Senior Living, we recognize reducing our portfolio concentration in Brookdale is a high priority.
Third, we have somewhat elevated leverage as compared to our peers and historical averages. We are prepared to improve our balance sheet metrics progressively over the next 2 to 3 years. Fourth, as you continue to get to know our next generation of leaders, we believe that you will quickly gain confidence in our ability to execute and to grow prudently. And finally, as part of sustained credibility, we will be a leader in transparency, predictability and clarity to the fullest extent possible.
Let me acknowledge upfront that this earnings call has some inherent limitations because some of what we are doing is still in progress, and detailed information in some areas is restricted by the fact that we are in registration with the SEC for our spin transaction and we are not yet effective. We will do the best we can to be responsive to your questions, but we really look forward to getting through the next several months when all of the things we are doing will become much clearer when the comprehensive plan we are implementing can be shared with you fully.
Today, we will cover details of our second quarter results and portfolio performance, and we'll give you an update on our spinoff of HCR ManorCare, which is well underway and expected to be completed early in the fourth quarter.
I'm happy to report that we now have a name for the new spin company. We call it Quality Care Properties or QCP. I'm also happy to report that the remaining 75% of our portfolio, which is predominantly private pay, is performing at or above plan and will anchor HCP's organic growth following the spin.
Let me now turn things over to Tom Herzog, who will focus on our quarterly results and financial performance.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. Today, I will cover several topics: first, our second quarter results; second, an update on our dispositions and RIDEA 2 transaction; third, our balance sheet and financing plan; and finally, our updated 2016 guidance.I'll start with ou
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. Today, I will cover several topics: first, our second quarter results; second, an update on our dispositions and RIDEA 2 transaction; third, our balance sheet and financing plan; and finally, our updated 2016 guidance.
I'll start with our results. During the second quarter, we reported NAREIT FFO of $0.71 per share, which included a negative $0.03 per share of transaction-related costs, substantially all of which were spin related. Excluding these costs, we recorded FFO as adjusted of $0.74 per share and FAD of $0.72 per share.
Also impacting the quarter were gains of $0.03 per share that resulted from monetizing our share in the appreciation of 2 participating development loans in our senior housing segment. Note that there was a similar gain of $0.02 per share in the prior year period.
Both NAREIT FFO and FFO as adjusted for the quarter reflect an $0.08 per share year-over-year reduction from placing the HCR ManorCare lease on cash basis beginning on January 1 of this year, as discussed on our February earnings call.
Looking at same property performance, our overall year-over-year same-store cash NOI grew at 4% in the second quarter. Excluding HCR ManorCare and the other 28 assets included in the spin to QCP, HCP RemainCo generated solid year-over-year same-store cash NOI growth of 4.4% for the quarter, led by strong leasing momentum in life science, which grew at 8.6%, driven by the burn-off of rent abatements, contractual rent steps and lease-up activities, bringing occupancy to a new all-time high of 98.7%, and strong RIDEA growth of 5.6% in the quarter, which Justin will cover momentarily.
Moving on to dispositions and RIDEA 2 transaction. We are on track to complete $1.25 billion of dispositions in 2016, inclusive of the previously announced RIDEA 2 transaction, of which $350 million has closed and the remaining $900 million is committed and expected to close by year-end. As will be further discussed in a moment, proceeds will be used primarily to reduce leverage and recycle into other investments.
Significant transactions include: $130 million from the sale of a portfolio of 5 skilled nursing and 2 assisted living facilities operated by Trilogy, which closed in June; $50 million from the monetization of 2 senior housing development loans during the quarter; $470 million of total proceeds to HCP from the pending RIDEA 2 joint venture transaction announced last quarter from selling a 40% stake in the venture for $110 million and raising $360 million of new third-party debt.
Note that this has been revised from a previously disclosed estimate of $740 million due to our decision to reduce the size of the new third-party mortgage debt, allowing us to reduce leverage more quickly compared to our previous plan. The transaction is expected to close in the fourth quarter. The majority of the remaining $600 million of dispositions represents previously announced transactions, including Phase 1 of the Genentech purchase option expected to close November and the sales of a life science facility, a medical office building and nonstrategic HCR ManorCare assets.
Next, our balance sheet and financing plan. During the quarter, we prepaid $200 million of mortgage debt at 6.6%. Our financial leverage improved by 90 basis points from the prior quarter to 44.6% at the end of second quarter. And we ended the quarter with $1.2 billion of immediate liquidity from our revolver plus unrestricted cash.
Now, I'll provide an update on our overall financing plan for HCP and QCP. Our current financing plan anticipates raising up to $3.8 billion of proceeds in aggregate from a combination of: first, $0.9 billion from dispositions and the RIDEA 2 transaction during the second half of the year as reflected in our guidance, which I just discussed; and second, $2.9 billion not included in our guidance from QCP financing to be distributed to HCP and additional asset sales.
The $3.8 billion of proceeds will be used as follows: first, the repayment of $3.3 billion of debt consisting of $2.4 billion of bonds and secured debt maturities at a 6.3% blended rate, representing substantially all scheduled debt maturities through the end of 2018, plus $0.9 billion currently outstanding under our revolver; and the remaining proceeds of $0.5 billion will be used to finance pending acquisitions during the second half of 2016 totaling $0.2 billion, with the remainder used for spin transaction costs, debt prepayment costs and committed development fundings.
Our updated financing plan improves HCP RemainCo's balance sheet relative to our targets communicated last quarter. Our target net debt to EBITDA is expected to improve from 6.6x to 6.25x, and our target financial leverage to improve from 45.5% to 43.5%.
Finally, our 2016 guidance. Full year 2016 guidance updated today represents our performance expectations for the entire HCP portfolio and does not reflect the spin transaction. It does reflect the impact of the $1.25 billion of dispositions inclusive of RIDEA 2 that I just discussed, our announced investment activities and contractual rent from HCR ManorCare, inclusive of the 3% rent escalator that took effect on April 1.
With that said, HCP's portfolio continues to perform well, and we expect our full year 2016 NAREIT FFO to range from $2.72 to $2.78 per share, reflecting $0.08 per share of transaction costs, primarily for spin-related professional fees realized before completion, which are expensed as incurred, and $0.03 per share of previously announced severance-related charges in the third quarter.
Excluding the transaction costs and the severance-related charges, we are raising FFO as adjusted to $2.83 to $2.89 per share from the previous range of $2.77 to $2.83 per share, inclusive of the $0.03 per share gain I described earlier.
We're also raising our FAD guidance to $2.68 to $2.74 per share from the previous range of $2.65 to $2.71 per share. We are reaffirming our overall same-store cash NOI year-over-year growth forecast of 1.5% to 2.5% and are projecting same-store growth for HCP RemainCo's portfolio, which primarily consists of private pay senior housing, life science and medical office assets, to increase between 2.3% and 3.3% when excluding the assets being spun off to QCP.
While not reflected in our 2016 guidance, the incremental impact from the spin transaction will include transferring approximately $485 million of annual in-place rental income to QCP and prepaying HCP debt using cash proceeds raised by QCP and additional asset sales. Additional future spin transaction-related costs, including the impact in EPS and NAREIT FFO, will be provided upon completion of the transaction.
Now let me turn the call over to Justin.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. We had a relatively quiet quarter, announcing $111 million of investments in the Life Science segment, bringing our year-to-date total investments to $475 million, substantially all in private pay sectors. But more importantly, let me high
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. We had a relatively quiet quarter, announcing $111 million of investments in the Life Science segment, bringing our year-to-date total investments to $475 million, substantially all in private pay sectors. But more importantly, let me highlight the performance of the remaining 75% of our portfolio that will anchor HCP's future organic growth and why we believe this portfolio stands up among the best in the industry.
HCP post spin will have 95% of our income derived from private pay sources across senior housing, life science and medical properties. In senior housing, as Tom mentioned, we had another quarter of strong growth in our 70-community same-store RIDEA portfolio of 5.6%, bringing our year-to-date growth to 7.5%, driven by occupancy improvement of 150 basis points in the quarter, which was 170 basis points above the overall industry.
We were also able to achieve strong rate growth of 3.5%, again ahead of the industry average. The benefits of our revenue-enhancing capital investments are beginning to take shape, and we feel there is further room to grow in our markets. Our portfolio is positioned in markets with high senior population growth and has shown resilience to the threats of new supply.
Fewer than 15% of our communities have been impacted by recent openings since the start of 2015. Occupancy in our top 5 markets improved 100 basis points in the second quarter from prior year to 91% while growth for the remaining portfolio was even stronger. Our diverse portfolio by geography and care mix allows us to mitigate the concentration risk of new supply and labor challenges.
Although our communities located in our top markets enjoyed NOI growth comparable to our peers, our communities located outside the primary markets enjoyed same-store NOI growth of 13% over the prior year. We firmly believe that quality returns are determined by local market fundamentals and the execution of the operations.
As Mike mentioned, we value our Brookdale relationship. We are diversified within Brookdale across independent living, assisted living, memory care and continuing care retirement communities in a variety of structures, including triple-net leases and RIDEA joint ventures, and we are encouraged by the direction of the company.
However, we are mindful of the Brookdale concentration post spin and remain focused on the performance management of their communities through the team's efforts. We are focused with Brookdale in finding mutually beneficial ways to address our concentration and improve the overall quality of the portfolio.
On the MOB front, 82% of our properties are located on campus, with 95% affiliated with over 200 health systems. One of the hallmark characteristics of our MOB platform is its consistent and predictable performance, evidenced by having 75% tenant retention rate year-to-date and 2.7% same-store growth outlook for the year at the midpoint. We are the largest owner and developer of life science real estate on the West Coast, concentrated in 2 of the top 3 markets in the country where fundamentals continue to be very favorable.
We reported another all-time high occupancy and strong same-store outlook for the year at a midpoint of 7.4%. The Cove development in South San Francisco continues to progress well. The Phase 1 buildings are substantially complete and steel is up on the second phase buildings. We are excited to welcome our first tenant, Denali Therapeutics, moving in this week and are -- we are on schedule for CytomX Therapeutics to take occupancy in early October. Demand continues to be strong, and we look forward to providing further updates in the near future.
Now, I'll cover the HCR ManorCare performance update. For the second quarter of 2016, HCR ManorCare reported normalized EBITDAR of $132 million, bringing the year-to-date total to $263 million. HCR ManorCare's normalized fixed charge coverage ratio for the trailing 12 months was 1.03x, down 3 basis points from Q1, driven by continued industry headwinds, a weaker flu season and a 3% rent increase effective in April. Note that fixed charge coverage was also burdened by $9 million of EBITDAR losses from the 33 nonstrategic assets that have sold to date.
Upon excluding these EBITDAR losses and the rent associated with the assets, the trailing 12-month normalized fixed charge coverage would have been 1.07x. As a reminder, there are 17 additional assets that are planned to be sold by early 2017. HCR ManorCare ended the quarter with $174 million of cash and cash equivalents.
Now I'll turn the call back over to Mike.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Justin. Let me provide now an update on the spin transaction and also take the opportunity to introduce Mark Ordan, our designated CEO for QCP to make some remarks. The executive team for QCP has been assembled, and Mark will speak to that in a mo
componenttext:
Thanks, Justin. Let me provide now an update on the spin transaction and also take the opportunity to introduce Mark Ordan, our designated CEO for QCP to make some remarks. The executive team for QCP has been assembled, and Mark will speak to that in a moment. We have filed the first amendment to our Form 10. We are in the process with our debt financing for QCP. Market conditions are stable, and we're gearing up with our financial advisers, Barclays and Morgan Stanley, to begin formal marketing shortly.
We continue to believe firmly that forming QCP represents the superior vehicle with flexibility to unlock significant embedded value in the HCR ManorCare portfolio. Let me turn it over now to Mark Ordan to give us his perspective.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. As Mike mentioned, we are progressing in every area necessary to launch the spin of our new company, Quality Care Properties or QCP. We have a highly experienced management team, with Greg Neeb as our President and Chief Investment Office
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. As Mike mentioned, we are progressing in every area necessary to launch the spin of our new company, Quality Care Properties or QCP. We have a highly experienced management team, with Greg Neeb as our President and Chief Investment Officer and Marc Richards as our Chief Financial Officer.
I worked closely with Greg and Mark for the past decade at several companies, most applicably, the turnaround of Sunrise Senior Living where we both owned and operated skilled nursing facilities and a major assisted living and memory care platform. We have a demonstrated track record of actively managing real estate and healthcare operations with a proven ability to work through challenging situations to reach an optimal outcome for our shareholders. We look forward to leading QCP.
We have also made good progress on forming our Board of Directors. We will soon be announcing a highly-qualified board of 6 independent directors joining me, with experience across the health care, real estate, investing, finance and legal sectors.
As Mike mentioned, we are moving along toward arranging our debt financing, which will be in place for the spin, and we will then be able to speak specifically to the debt cost and structure. QCP will emerge with an appropriate capital structure to support our business strategy. We will be a major player in a vital, irreplaceable and growing sector within health care.
As inception, QCP will own a portfolio of 338 properties diversified across 30 states, primarily consisting of post-acute/skilled nursing and private pay senior housing facilities operated by HCR ManorCare. QCP's in-place rental income will be approximately $485 million, and we estimate our annual G&A run rate to be just over $20 million. Our near-term goal will be to manage actively our portfolio and relationship with HCR ManorCare in order to develop a comprehensive solution that will unlock the real estate value in the portfolio. We have a wide variety of alternatives that we can pursue, and we will work with HCR ManorCare's management team to improve the portfolio's operating performance and lease coverage.
The QCP dividend, of course, will be set by our independent board. I believe that given our high tenant concentration in one operator with lease coverage that has declined in recent periods, it'll be most important for QCP to build up near-term liquidity. Therefore, it's my expectation that we will most likely begin with a low to modest dividend. We will seek to maximize value for investors through total shareholder return. Of course, we'll have the option to grow into a higher dividend level over time as lease coverage stabilizes.
I'll conclude by saying that I'm very pleased by the excellent collaboration among my team and the HCP board, management team and advisers to launch a first-class company, which will unlock value for HCP and future QCP shareholders. In my role as adviser to HCP, I've been able to see firsthand the company's careful determination to build its next chapter. Our time together has been a pleasure, and we all look forward to the launch of QCP and to rolling up our sleeves to seek a comprehensive solution with HCR ManorCare.
We look forward to meeting with our investors and potential investors in the coming weeks and months. Mike?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. In closing, let me summarize a few important points. Our spin is on track and the financing process is underway. The remaining 75% of our portfolio has continued to perform very well, with all sectors producing strong growth. We're happy wit
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark. In closing, let me summarize a few important points. Our spin is on track and the financing process is underway. The remaining 75% of our portfolio has continued to perform very well, with all sectors producing strong growth. We're happy with our partnership with Brookdale and the growth that our RIDEA portfolio has achieved. And we will continue to work with them to identify ways to address the concentration in a way that is strategic for both companies.
We maintain an investment-grade balance sheet and have plans in place to improve our leverage profile further. And most importantly, we have assembled an incredibly talented team that will be able to drive value for our shareholders. More to come on this topic in the coming months as we bring HCP 3.0 forward.
With that, I will turn it back to the operator to open the line for questions. Thank you.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from Vikram Malhotra from Morgan Stanley.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Landon Park on for Vikram. Just wondering if we could start out talking about Brookdale a little bit more and the triple-net senior housing portfolio. Just how are you approaching that as several big buckets seemed to move down in terms of coverag
componenttext: This is Landon Park on for Vikram. Just wondering if we could start out talking about Brookdale a little bit more and the triple-net senior housing portfolio. Just how are you approaching that as several big buckets seemed to move down in terms of coverage if you look at Sunrise. And then more specifically on Brookdale, the negotiations that they say that you're in regarding some of their underperforming assets and then just longer term, how you're approaching the risk in that portfolio.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Justin. We mentioned on our last call that we're in discussions with Brookdale regarding 25 triple-net assets, and those assets are, in fact, a drag on the triple-net portfolio. I'll note that while we're in negotiations, I think that when we come
componenttext: This is Justin. We mentioned on our last call that we're in discussions with Brookdale regarding 25 triple-net assets, and those assets are, in fact, a drag on the triple-net portfolio. I'll note that while we're in negotiations, I think that when we come out of this, there'll be winners on both sides of the table, so we've been taking our time trying to get a transaction that creates a win for HCP and that's comfortable for Brookdale as well. And if you look at their overall company, we're encouraged by the new team that's in place. There's a lot of focus on refining systems, putting new controls in place. They've reorganized the company in terms of their oversight over the field. You've probably noted that after we followed Brookdale, a lot of confidence coming from the management team to their Investor Day and on the earnings call today. So we're encouraged by the overall performance of the company. Meanwhile, we're mindful of the concentration that HCP will have -- on pre-spin, we're around 25% concentrated; post spin, we go to around 34%. As Mike mentioned in his prepared remarks, that it will be a focus for us. We think that ongoing discussions with Brookdale to call the portfolio can help the concentration and ultimately help the credit quality of the lease moving forward. And then, of course, over time, by growing in other asset classes and what other operators, we'll be able to address the concentration as well.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sunrise had some slowness in entrance fee sales. We think that'll pick up throughout the rest of the year. I feel comfortable with their performance moving forward. The other buckets, we're addressing in a number of ways. We have some assets that are
componenttext: Yes, Sunrise had some slowness in entrance fee sales. We think that'll pick up throughout the rest of the year. I feel comfortable with their performance moving forward. The other buckets, we're addressing in a number of ways. We have some assets that are being sold back to operators. We have some transitions where we're moving to new operators. And then we've also converted some triple-net leased assets into RIDEA relationships. And net, we think that's neutral financially. But ultimately, the assets are going to be in better hands.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And can you just clarify on the RIDEA 2 sale, the change in proceeds there and exactly what's happening there?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start quick, and then I'll hand it over to Tom. I just wanted to note that the transaction itself, from an overall economic standpoint, has not changed. When we made that trade, we agreed to a price that was supported a 6.5% cap on a trailing basis.
componenttext: I'll start quick, and then I'll hand it over to Tom. I just wanted to note that the transaction itself, from an overall economic standpoint, has not changed. When we made that trade, we agreed to a price that was supported a 6.5% cap on a trailing basis. And so the equity payment from our partner is -- has not changed. And I'll hand it to Tom.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Landon. So what we're looking at, as Justin indicated, regardless of how we finance it, we still have our same share in the real estate in that joint venture and it's at a 6.5% trailing cap rate. And again -- so that part doesn't change. What has cha
componenttext: Yes, Landon. So what we're looking at, as Justin indicated, regardless of how we finance it, we still have our same share in the real estate in that joint venture and it's at a 6.5% trailing cap rate. And again -- so that part doesn't change. What has changed is how we're financing the entity. So we have this partnership, along with another one, where we have partners that would like to receive some proceeds. And we don't prefer to receive proceeds at the HCP level because we're more geared toward wanting to bring our leverage down more rapidly and improve our net debt to EBITDA. So the way to accomplish that is to put in place a third-party debt for the partner's share of that financing. And then we provide debt at the same rate for our share, which gets eliminated in consolidation as if that debt doesn't even exist from our perspective. So our financial position remains unchanged. So we did -- we're doing that with a couple of our partnerships. We also have a GBP revolver outstanding for $450 million. We intend to prepay that because there's no prepayment penalties on that, and we can reduce our leverage fairly substantially. That's where we come up with those leverage numbers that I spoke to in the script of coming somewhere in the vicinity of 45.5% to 46% leverage post spin, bringing it down to 43.5%, and from 6.6x net debt-to-EBITDA down to 6.25x net debt to EBITDA. It is that series of moves. One other thing I'd add is in prepayment of that GBP debt, of course, we have to pay attention to the hedging that we have on our GBP investments. So we'd enter into a simple cross-currency swap against one of our unsecured notes so that we stay hedged. So that's how we're thinking about the revised financing plan.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- let me just step back and talk about the coverage but also the performance outlook for HCR. You might remember that we gave a sensitivity range at the beginning of the year that started at $505 million and went to $555 million, and that's the EBITD
componenttext: The -- let me just step back and talk about the coverage but also the performance outlook for HCR. You might remember that we gave a sensitivity range at the beginning of the year that started at $505 million and went to $555 million, and that's the EBITDAR at the company level. At this time, as we look ahead, there's some pluses in the second half of the year. There's a 2-plus percent Medicare increase for skilled nursing and hospice. Seasonally, Q4 is generally strong, although that's not always the case. So as we look at that and incorporated feedback from the company, we point to the lower end of that range at this point in time and a corresponding fixed charge cover, be it 1.07 and 1.10. If you take out the impact that was picked up from the asset sales or the drag from the asset sales, you're about at 1.04. Another way to look at it though is that we have more asset sales to go. There's about $65 million more in sales coming. $10 million are under contract; total proceeds, we estimate to be around $54 million; and then we have another $7 million now to pick up the remaining amount. And we expect the $10 million to close by year-end and then the remaining amounts to close in the first quarter. But the timing of that sale can help us to get to that 1.1 cover.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And just one clarification, if I may. The target net debt, you mentioned EBITDA down to 6.6, is that a pro forma number, pro forma spin?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And just one clarification, if I may. The target net debt, you mentioned EBITDA down to 6.6, is that a pro forma number, pro forma spin?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's pro forma, the spin. And keep in mind, well, that...
componenttext: Yes, that's pro forma, the spin. And keep in mind, well, that...

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It'll be at 6.6 pro forma?
componenttext: It'll be at 6.6 pro forma?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It would be at 6.6 -- We called that mid-6, as I think, in the last call just to reconcile, but it's about 6.6. And then after we complete these financing activities over the next few months, that would drive it back down to the 6.25x, which, I mean, fran
componenttext: It would be at 6.6 -- We called that mid-6, as I think, in the last call just to reconcile, but it's about 6.6. And then after we complete these financing activities over the next few months, that would drive it back down to the 6.25x, which, I mean, frankly is part of our ongoing effort and plan to start to, patiently, over the next 2 to 3 years, work our way back to our BBB+ metrics. And then that's what we're thinking about as we looked at the leverage. And the net debt-to-EBITDAs, we're currently at a comfortable BBB. And we intend to take actions through a variety of measures to work our way back towards BBB+ metrics over the next 2 to 3 years, which is where we'd like to land.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Juan Sanabria from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Juan Sanabria from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. First, on the life science portfolio. Could you just give us a sense of how much free rent is still yet to burn off? And any sense that the market to market on the portfolio maturing through 2018 and how we should think about t
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. First, on the life science portfolio. Could you just give us a sense of how much free rent is still yet to burn off? And any sense that the market to market on the portfolio maturing through 2018 and how we should think about that?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, at a high level, I'm sure you noted that the occupancy is 98.7%. There's been solid growth due to the mark-to-market and also new leasing activity. However, as we look ahead, most of our leases are at market at this point. So we would anticipate hig
componenttext: Well, at a high level, I'm sure you noted that the occupancy is 98.7%. There's been solid growth due to the mark-to-market and also new leasing activity. However, as we look ahead, most of our leases are at market at this point. So we would anticipate high occupancy, but then organic growth due to the mark-to-market leasing would slow down a bit.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And any color on the free rent burning off or how much is left?
componenttext: And any color on the free rent burning off or how much is left?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Juan, this is John. Life science, when you sign a new lease, 7, 10 years generally, you have the first few months that's free rent. So you saw us increase our occupancy every quarter. We have sort of a new all-time high occupancy the last 4, 5 quarters ev
componenttext: Juan, this is John. Life science, when you sign a new lease, 7, 10 years generally, you have the first few months that's free rent. So you saw us increase our occupancy every quarter. We have sort of a new all-time high occupancy the last 4, 5 quarters every quarter, so that's going to phase out over time. But generally, in the longer-term lease, you have the first few month where you have that rent -- free rent, and that's what Tom talked about earlier in his prepared remarks, part of the 8-plus percent we put out this quarter, pertaining to sort of burn-off of those things. But you'll see that normalize over time, as Justin mentioned, the occupancy getting to that pretty high levels.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the hospital side, what's the driver of the deceleration over the back half of the year that's implied by the guidance that was adjusted down, if you can give us some color on that.
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the hospital side, what's the driver of the deceleration over the back half of the year that's implied by the guidance that was adjusted down, if you can give us some color on that.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: There was a contractual rent reset that occurred. So we expect to tick up again next year. You'll see the growth back on a regular pace.
componenttext: There was a contractual rent reset that occurred. So we expect to tick up again next year. You'll see the growth back on a regular pace.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what was the rent reset? What was the coverage? And where did it go? I guess, where was it from and where does it go to? And how big was that?
componenttext: And what was the rent reset? What was the coverage? And where did it go? I guess, where was it from and where does it go to? And how big was that?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Juan, it's one of -- first of all, our hospital portfolio, as you know, it's pretty small, and it's one of the hospital tenants where -- what we did was we spread out a rent reduction previously under the old contract, would have been a 1 -- over a 1-year
componenttext: Juan, it's one of -- first of all, our hospital portfolio, as you know, it's pretty small, and it's one of the hospital tenants where -- what we did was we spread out a rent reduction previously under the old contract, would have been a 1 -- over a 1-year period, which spreaded out over a longer period of time. And economically speaking, it doesn't change the cash flows under the lease. It's just on a timing standpoint. So from 2016, the back half of the year, you saw the cash same-store growth. That's why you noted in terms of midpoint of the range. And we just sort of spread it over a longer period of time, and part of that trickled into the latter half of this year.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one last quick one. CapEx expectations for the RIDEA portfolio. You talked about seeing some of the benefit from some of the redevelopment CapEx. But what should we expect spend maybe per unit from here?
componenttext: Okay. And just one last quick one. CapEx expectations for the RIDEA portfolio. You talked about seeing some of the benefit from some of the redevelopment CapEx. But what should we expect spend maybe per unit from here?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're spending between $4,000 or $5,000 a unit. About 2/3 of that is going into major refreshes or repositioning of the assets. The rest is retained. They're -- we're not getting into forecasting for next year, but I would anticipate there'll be some carr
componenttext: We're spending between $4,000 or $5,000 a unit. About 2/3 of that is going into major refreshes or repositioning of the assets. The rest is retained. They're -- we're not getting into forecasting for next year, but I would anticipate there'll be some carryover from some projects that are underway. But as you noted, we're actually quite pleased with the results we're seeing. We've dug into several of the markets where we've had the projects completed. We track the cash flow performance and occupancy of those assets relative to market and we're finding that we're outperforming. So there's definitely a net benefit in the early going from these capital expenditures. However, as we've looked at this and with Tom on board now, we're going to make this a priority topic. We're going to revamp and enhance our internal tracking, and it'll help us to articulate it more clearly, externally as well. In fact, maybe Tom can mention a few of the highlights and how we're going to approach this.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll just take a minute on it. When we think about revenue-enhancing CapEx, and Justin and I both worked around this for a long time, so we just need to put in place the review processes and systems to capture returns that we already know are inheren
componenttext: Yes, I'll just take a minute on it. When we think about revenue-enhancing CapEx, and Justin and I both worked around this for a long time, so we just need to put in place the review processes and systems to capture returns that we already know are inherent in a lot of the work that we're doing. But to put more rigor around it, we think about the type of spend that it is, that's exterior common areas, it's kitchen, bath, FF&E, et cetera. A lot of the stuff might have a 12-year life. It usually requires a fairly high cash on cash return in the front-end, probably has an average life somewhere in the vicinity of 12 years, we're going to fine-tune this through our discussions. We're obviously going to want to underwrite to an IRR a certain number of basis points above our WAC to make sure that there's honesty in the projects that we approve, that there is a positive return to our investors and then have a view on the impact on the same-store portfolio growth, so that again, we've got a feel for what it does to the numbers. Now as you know, over time, with these types of programs, the rollover effect occurs and then that becomes a smaller number, the same-store impact from it. But these are things that Justin and I and others on the team are going to get underneath and be ready to speak to in the future.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Nick Yulico.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Nick Yulico.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to go back to, Mark, your comments on looking at alternatives to work with HCR ManorCare. It seems like the most obvious candidate here would be to eventually reduce the rents and in exchange, QCP gets more equity in the OpCo at HCR ManorCare.
componenttext: I just want to go back to, Mark, your comments on looking at alternatives to work with HCR ManorCare. It seems like the most obvious candidate here would be to eventually reduce the rents and in exchange, QCP gets more equity in the OpCo at HCR ManorCare. But this could result in QCP having to shed its REIT status. So I guess, how are -- how is the -- how are you and the board go -- weigh that issue about as an alternative looking to get something in return for a rent cut, but it -- resulting in you guys maybe having to lose your REIT status?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, by design, QCP has, as we've said several times, the tools and flexibility to work with HCR ManorCare's management team, which we look forward to doing to finding, for lack of a better phrase, the comprehensive solution. So we could go down the path
componenttext: Well, by design, QCP has, as we've said several times, the tools and flexibility to work with HCR ManorCare's management team, which we look forward to doing to finding, for lack of a better phrase, the comprehensive solution. So we could go down the path that you outlined. We could go down several paths. But we think there's great long-term value in that portfolio, and we look forward to working with ManorCare to unlock that. And our expectation is that we're going to be a REIT and that we'll be able to work out our issues and maintain that REIT status, but that remains to be seen. The key point, I think for an HCP shareholder, is that this is a vehicle that's more suited. Especially given our 100% focus on working with ManorCare, this is a vehicle that's more suited to working this out than HCP would have been, so a shareholder should be able to benefit from both.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then going back to your comments about the dividend of QCP being low to modest, looking to build up near-term liquidity. I mean, what exactly does low to modest mean? I mean, are you referring to an absolute dollar amount, a payout ratio? How sh
componenttext: Okay. And then going back to your comments about the dividend of QCP being low to modest, looking to build up near-term liquidity. I mean, what exactly does low to modest mean? I mean, are you referring to an absolute dollar amount, a payout ratio? How should we think about that?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think I'm referring to a philosophy of getting ahead of myself because our board obviously and our company is not yet established. But I would say that I think it's just good corporate finance to expect that we would start out modestly, I'm talking
componenttext: No, I think I'm referring to a philosophy of getting ahead of myself because our board obviously and our company is not yet established. But I would say that I think it's just good corporate finance to expect that we would start out modestly, I'm talking philosophically, to get our footing and where we then have room to grow from there. So I meant nothing more than that and I certainly could not pinpoint a dollar amount or payout ratio today.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And then, I guess, just lastly is -- you're not sort of saying what the -- in the past, you said the HCP, you said that the debt could be at some sort of 5x debt-to-EBITDA type of level for the SpinCo. Is that still the case? And maybe you cou
componenttext: Okay, okay. And then, I guess, just lastly is -- you're not sort of saying what the -- in the past, you said the HCP, you said that the debt could be at some sort of 5x debt-to-EBITDA type of level for the SpinCo. Is that still the case? And maybe you could talk a little bit more about the types of financing you're trying to do, whether it's secured, leveraged loans, financing. And then as we think about ultimately what HCP is doing here, which is raising debt at SpinCo to pay off your debt at HCP of a sort of 6.3% rate, I think you said. Is the rate -- I mean, is that going to be just the debt for debt? Is that going to be a neutral event? Is it going to be a dilutive? Is it going to be accretive? I mean, how should we think about the rate of what you're trying to raise versus payoff?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Multiple part question, good question, but let me hit the pieces. First -- your first question was the 5.0x. We really start out more in the mid-3s as far as net debt to EBITDA based on current rents. And that 5.0x that you're referencing would be somebod
componenttext: Multiple part question, good question, but let me hit the pieces. First -- your first question was the 5.0x. We really start out more in the mid-3s as far as net debt to EBITDA based on current rents. And that 5.0x that you're referencing would be somebody in the Street looking at it and modifying or underwriting a rent at a 1.3x on the skilled and 1.1x on the assisted. That is not where we're at right now. So I would just start by saying it's more in that mid to upper 3s as to where we'd stand on day 1 and -- but yet to be determined. As far as the different types of financing that could occur, we had looked at 3. I mean, we could enter into term loans, A and B notes, for instance, CMBS which really doesn't work that well in skilled space and of course -- and there's corporate bonds. We have explored all 3 with our bankers. I think the CMBS probably is not the route to go. It could very well be a combination of term loans and corporate bonds. And we actually do have a path that we're looking at right now, but it would be premature for me to provide you our thoughts on because I'd like to see where it plays out over the next couple of weeks. As far as the rate of repayment of the debt, the 6.3% rate is what I said in my script. So is that accretive or dilutive? Well, let's put it this way. It comes at a -- what I would think a fairly modest prepayment penalty to clear out all of our debt or the vast majority of it for 2016, '17 and '18 at the HCP level. It's pretty high-level rate debt. And then we have to see what that debt cost is at the QCP level to look at what it looks like across the combined enterprises, not that they won't totally trade separately, but when you're just looking at the 2 together at period 0. So we'll see where that plays out. The other thing that I would mention is you're probably wondering how do the high-yield markets look right now. The fact is they look favorable. So I'll remind you, when you're comparing to other executions that are out there, that QCP is going to be a REIT, and it's backed by a full portfolio of real estate assets. There's been excellent activity over the last couple of weeks and before that. And that financing has been around LBOs, acquisitions, opportunistic refinancings, et cetera, so the transactions -- these transactions have been met with very, very strong demand because investors are putting a lot of dollars to work. If you go back to the beginning of the year and you look at the single B index, and I'm not saying that's where we're at specifically, but we'll be below investment grade at QCP, it's at 6 point -- I think the number I got yesterday was about 6.7% versus 8.6% at the beginning of the year. So the markets have been quite favorable, and the indications that we get in all preliminary discussions are quite favorable as well.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Tyler from Green Street Advisers.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Tyler from Green Street Advisers.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, just following up on that point when you broke out the leverage, answering Nick's question there, I didn't hear you mention anything related to seller financing, meaning HCP extending any financing directly to QCP. I just want to make sure I'm hearin
componenttext: Tom, just following up on that point when you broke out the leverage, answering Nick's question there, I didn't hear you mention anything related to seller financing, meaning HCP extending any financing directly to QCP. I just want to make sure I'm hearing that correctly and want to understand your thinking on that topic at this point.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you heard me correctly. I did not allude to seller financing because as we go out to the market, we've got to see how it all lines out, but it's our initial goal that we'll see if we can get this financed without seller financing. That would be a pre
componenttext: Yes, you heard me correctly. I did not allude to seller financing because as we go out to the market, we've got to see how it all lines out, but it's our initial goal that we'll see if we can get this financed without seller financing. That would be a preference. But at the same time, we have to see what the market holds. We've got a lot of different alternatives that we can consider. So I don't want to pin us down to anything specific. But in the numbers that I gave and the commentary that I provided, there's some no seller financing.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one other and maybe it's for you, Mark, on ManorCare. But in light of the Department of Justice settlement or pending settlement that Genesis had announced, I'm wondering what read-through there might be, if any, to the ongoing suit at Mano
componenttext: Okay. And then one other and maybe it's for you, Mark, on ManorCare. But in light of the Department of Justice settlement or pending settlement that Genesis had announced, I'm wondering what read-through there might be, if any, to the ongoing suit at ManorCare with the DOJ, and if there's any update that you could provide on that at this point.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'll jump in and take that, and then Mark, you can add if you want. But as we look at the DOJ case, it's still early in the process, just starting discovery. There really is no way of projecting a potential outcome at this point, but we're alread
componenttext: I guess, I'll jump in and take that, and then Mark, you can add if you want. But as we look at the DOJ case, it's still early in the process, just starting discovery. There really is no way of projecting a potential outcome at this point, but we're already seeing some settlements and they appear to be manageable, so that's probably all that we can say at this point on that topic.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Last one I had, Justin, on the Brookdale portfolio and their results last night, occupancy slowed a little bit but management talked about some strength in June. And I'm just wondering, in your portfolio, you saw a little bit of a decline quarter-ov
componenttext: Okay. Last one I had, Justin, on the Brookdale portfolio and their results last night, occupancy slowed a little bit but management talked about some strength in June. And I'm just wondering, in your portfolio, you saw a little bit of a decline quarter-over-quarter. But did you see similar strength in June? And are you expecting that occupancy will head higher maybe in the back half of the year? Or I'm just curious on the outlook given some competitive pressure on the way.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what I'll do is this. I'll speak to our expectations in terms of performance in our RIDEA portfolio. And when you take that whole bucket of 70 communities that I spoke to during my prepared remarks, as we look forward, we could see the -- although
componenttext: I think what I'll do is this. I'll speak to our expectations in terms of performance in our RIDEA portfolio. And when you take that whole bucket of 70 communities that I spoke to during my prepared remarks, as we look forward, we could see the -- although the performance has started out pretty hot in the beginning of the year, we can see the total year coming in around 4% to 5%, which would have been better than our early expectations at the beginning of the year for that same portfolio. But what you're facing in the second half of the year, you have some of these supply in some of our markets. You also have some more labor pressure that we'll face as well. Q3 tends to be a softer quarter seasonally. Brookdale has had some remarks on their call that were favorable leading into Q3. But in terms of our RIDEA expectations, we're expecting a solid year at 4% to 5%, but potentially a little bit of a softer back half of the year. And then in terms of the triple-net portfolio, that performance, to your point, doesn't perfectly track the Brookdale corporate performance but it's pretty close. So I would really defer it to Brookdale's management commentary in terms of overall company expectations as it relates to our triple-net portfolio.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chad Vanacore from Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chad Vanacore from Stifel.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016

componenttext: So you've got a contemplated leverage, and you know that you're -- since you're looking at maybe secured and unsecured corporate debt for the SpinCo, so at what ranges of rates do you think you could get on each of those pieces?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd ask the same question if I were in your shoes. But we're in the middle of the process right now, the -- some of us folks at HCP and Mark and our bankers. And although I'd like to tell you where we're at, it would be premature. We're going to have
componenttext: Yes, I'd ask the same question if I were in your shoes. But we're in the middle of the process right now, the -- some of us folks at HCP and Mark and our bankers. And although I'd like to tell you where we're at, it would be premature. We're going to have to hold that one back until we get out and we market and have a feel for -- a little                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         closer feel for where we're at.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it's really too early to say what the appetite from investors would be?
componenttext: Okay. So it's really too early to say what the appetite from investors would be?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll put it this way. The appetite for investors at this point has been very favorable. We feel confident. But until we get closer, we probably can't comment a whole lot more than that.
componenttext: Yes. I'll put it this way. The appetite for investors at this point has been very favorable. We feel confident. But until we get closer, we probably can't comment a whole lot more than that.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, then. Let's think about -- At the SG&A, you said spin may be $21 million or $23 million on -- with $45 of rent. That just south of 5% of revenue. Is that fully baked to include stock comp and other costs that are typically in G&A?
componenttext: Okay, then. Let's think about -- At the SG&A, you said spin may be $21 million or $23 million on -- with $45 of rent. That just south of 5% of revenue. Is that fully baked to include stock comp and other costs that are typically in G&A?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just thinking about your dividend policy on the spin, knowing that it's going to be set by the board, what are some good market comps that are helping you to determine what an appropriate dividend is there?
componenttext: Okay. And then just thinking about your dividend policy on the spin, knowing that it's going to be set by the board, what are some good market comps that are helping you to determine what an appropriate dividend is there?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think like any company, we would look at our cash flow, our expected cash flow since this is -- QCP's whole reason for being is to work out a full solution with its one tenant. I think that's a decision that the board will make. And as I said earl
componenttext: Well, I think like any company, we would look at our cash flow, our expected cash flow since this is -- QCP's whole reason for being is to work out a full solution with its one tenant. I think that's a decision that the board will make. And as I said earlier, it's a corporate finance 101 decision. We'll want to build cash and once we get a sense of our stability, set our dividend policy. I don't think there's an exact comp to this. It's a little bit of a one-off.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Justin, just thinking about the senior housing portfolio. You mentioned maybe some supply and some wage pressures in the back half. Can you point to any specific markets that you're seeing supply in and then how much of the your NOI could or wo
componenttext: All right. Justin, just thinking about the senior housing portfolio. You mentioned maybe some supply and some wage pressures in the back half. Can you point to any specific markets that you're seeing supply in and then how much of the your NOI could or would be impacted?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, about 20% of our NOI in the RIDEA portfolio is exposed to new supply or 15% of our communities. We've had pretty good results where we face new supply to date. Occupancy typically comes under pressure. We've had an exception to that where we had an i
componenttext: Yes, about 20% of our NOI in the RIDEA portfolio is exposed to new supply or 15% of our communities. We've had pretty good results where we face new supply to date. Occupancy typically comes under pressure. We've had an exception to that where we had an independent living portfolio that was concentrated in Houston, for instance, that performs quite well. What tends to happen is you'll have occupancy be impacted in the market and therefore, in your community within that market, but rate tends to hold. So we're still seeing EBITDAR growth or NOI growth in communities that are impacted by new supply to date. However, as we look forward and trying to predict performance, we're going to be conservative and anticipate some impact. On the wage front, we find it really interesting that our communities that are located in the top 31 MSAs are actually more impacted by wage increases than our secondary markets. In fact, they're substantially more impacted, so there's pressure there as well.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Smedes Rose from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Smedes Rose from Citi.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask just about the employment contract that was detailed in your Form 10 this morning from -- for Mark. While we know that attracting executives costs money, it just seems like a lot of the payments and the size are quite high, and I wanted to
componenttext: I wanted to ask just about the employment contract that was detailed in your Form 10 this morning from -- for Mark. While we know that attracting executives costs money, it just seems like a lot of the payments and the size are quite high, and I wanted to ask you if you could sort of highlight your thinking around the agreement? And particularly, it seems like there's an opportunity to make several million dollars really quite early on in employment and just be interesting to hear some of your thoughts around this.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is Mark. I mean, I'd say that I think if you look at the contract, it's overwhelmingly weighted toward creating upside in the portfolio. So that's what attracted me to this. This is a long-term value play.
componenttext: Well, this is Mark. I mean, I'd say that I think if you look at the contract, it's overwhelmingly weighted toward creating upside in the portfolio. So that's what attracted me to this. This is a long-term value play.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mike McKee. I just emphasized the same thing. We're delighted that one, we have Mark and his team available. As he said and I would reiterate, it's been a delight to work with them, and I think that HCR ManorCare will find a real partner to w
componenttext: Yes, this is Mike McKee. I just emphasized the same thing. We're delighted that one, we have Mark and his team available. As he said and I would reiterate, it's been a delight to work with them, and I think that HCR ManorCare will find a real partner to work with. There's no question that a comprehensive plan, some new path needs to be developed, and Mark and his team are the right counterparty to do that. And we did a negotiating compensation, as Mark mentioned, highly weighted towards incentives. So as shareholder value is developed, he has an opportunity to be aligned with that objective. So we're glad that's in place. We're glad we could put it in the Form 10. And we're looking forward to getting the company's rest of its governance and so forth put together over the next 6 or 8 weeks, and they'll be ready to launch as a new public company.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I wanted to ask you too on -- you mentioned some thoughts around the dividend from the ManorCare spin. Could you just talk about your goals of reducing leverage at HCP and how you think about the dividend at HCP, which will likely have to be reset?
componenttext: Okay. I wanted to ask you too on -- you mentioned some thoughts around the dividend from the ManorCare spin. Could you just talk about your goals of reducing leverage at HCP and how you think about the dividend at HCP, which will likely have to be reset? I mean, is that an opportunity to reduce your payout ratio? Do you have any targets in mind to achieve your targeted leverage levels more quickly?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, this is Tom. My thinking and in talking with the senior management team here is that we bring this leverage back to the BBB+ levels with some degree of patience over time in a variety of ways. So it's not something that we have to do quickly.
componenttext: Well, again, this is Tom. My thinking and in talking with the senior management team here is that we bring this leverage back to the BBB+ levels with some degree of patience over time in a variety of ways. So it's not something that we have to do quickly. And because -- I mean, obviously, you can take actions without moving very quickly, but then that puts pressure on FAD and cash flow growth and dividend growth. So that's not the intent. As we think about dividend, of course, I'll start by saying that's a board decision. But at the same time, we're at about 0.85x coverage, somewhere in that vicinity. And as we think forward, there's nothing that I -- would lead me to believe at this point that you should expect a dramatic change from that based on the post-spin HCP entity. But again, I will say again that, that's a final decision of the board, and there will be further conversations on that topic.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Carroll from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016

componenttext: Justin, real quick on HCR ManorCare. I believe earlier, you indicated that operating trends are trending towards the lower end of the previous 2016 outlook. What's driving this lower performance that maybe wasn't expected at the start of the year?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, actually, what I was pointing to was the range that we gave, which was $505 million to $555 million. And that there -- if you look at the $263 million that they've had year-to-date through the first half of the year and then consider some pluses, wh
componenttext: Well, actually, what I was pointing to was the range that we gave, which was $505 million to $555 million. And that there -- if you look at the $263 million that they've had year-to-date through the first half of the year and then consider some pluses, which is the Medicare increases in hospice net, typical Q4 seasonal lift, although we know from recent memory that, that doesn't always come through for us. And then the timing of the remaining asset sales that there's some support for performance that could be a little bit better than lower end of the range and could be close to the middle part of the range.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016

componenttext: Okay. There -- you're actually expecting it to be in the midpoint of that range, maybe a little bit higher?

componenttext: It could be middle or lower.

componenttext: Yes, those are within expectations.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last question, can you kind of give us an update on the company's investment strategy and how that's evolving? I know in the second quarter, it looks like you bought or had some focus on somewhat medical office buildings and the life scienc
componenttext: Okay. And then last question, can you kind of give us an update on the company's investment strategy and how that's evolving? I know in the second quarter, it looks like you bought or had some focus on somewhat medical office buildings and the life science asset and the new market for you. I mean, do you expand -- plan on expanding that life science portfolio? Do you want to go into different markets? If so, what markets are you interested in?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me point initially to the investment behavior we've had year-to-date and then a little bit about the go forward. But if you look at -- to your point, what we've done year-to-date, we've had investments, we have dispositions. About 2/3 of those in
componenttext: Yes, let me point initially to the investment behavior we've had year-to-date and then a little bit about the go forward. But if you look at -- to your point, what we've done year-to-date, we've had investments, we have dispositions. About 2/3 of those investments, just short of 2/3 was directed to the life science segment, sort of moving our private pay assets and core markets. We have development, we have redevelopment as well. Very high demand in San Diego and our Bay Area markets. And then if you look at the dispositions, about 2/3 of those were skilled nursing facilities. So you have a relationship where you're moving away from government reimbursement, you're moving into private pay assets. And if you look ahead at HCP, as I mentioned, and as Mike mentioned on a regular basis, we're going to have a portfolio that's -- that represents the 75% that's left post spin that's 95% private pay. And so as we look forward, we're going to move into those segments, which are senior housing, life science, medical office building. And we'll have more on the plan in upcoming calls. Certainly, there's lot of discussions underway in terms of -- as Mike has pointed out, HCP 3.0, what that's going to look like moving forward. But what we're most excited about is that the starting point is a very high-quality portfolio and a game plan to reposition the balance sheet, and then we'll have an investment pieces that we'll clearly articulate in the future.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rich Anderson from Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rich Anderson from Mizuho Securities.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Tom, earlier you mentioned the mid-3s multiple on current rents. I'm curious, will lenders be willing to make a deal like that when you consider the 0.83x facility coverage and declining situation there? Or does there have to be what we would estimate
componenttext: So Tom, earlier you mentioned the mid-3s multiple on current rents. I'm curious, will lenders be willing to make a deal like that when you consider the 0.83x facility coverage and declining situation there? Or does there have to be what we would estimate a 35% to 40% rent cut first before you can actually come and get a commitment to a financing package? And maybe that question can go for Mark or Tom or anybody.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd jump in. It's Mark. We're confident that we'll be able to finance these the way that Tom outlined before. So I think that people understand the value of the real estate, the strength that's in the portfolio, and despite the fact that recent tren
componenttext: Well, I'd jump in. It's Mark. We're confident that we'll be able to finance these the way that Tom outlined before. So I think that people understand the value of the real estate, the strength that's in the portfolio, and despite the fact that recent trends have been negative, that this is a clearly financeable company.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you expect the financing to happen on current rents initially?
componenttext: So you expect the financing to happen on current rents initially?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say that anybody looking at the real estate is going to think about a range of possible rents when they consider financing. And our expectation, I think, is reasonable that we're going to size it with that range in mind. So I don't think -- I don't re
componenttext: I'd say that anybody looking at the real estate is going to think about a range of possible rents when they consider financing. And our expectation, I think, is reasonable that we're going to size it with that range in mind. So I don't think -- I don't really see a problem.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd just add one thing, Rich. You mentioned the facility level coverage. The other thing that, as investors look at this financing, you got to keep in mind that what is behind the master lease is also the hospice operations, which threw off a lot of cash
componenttext: I'd just add one thing, Rich. You mentioned the facility level coverage. The other thing that, as investors look at this financing, you got to keep in mind that what is behind the master lease is also the hospice operations, which threw off a lot of cash flow and gave additional value to the lease arrangement itself. And that's part of what Mark's alluding to when he said there's a range of potential outcomes. And within his various opportunities, things that he'll be considering as he goes forward as well, but that -- those are the conversations we have with lenders.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016

componenttext: I would -- and you mean, the commitment on the debt?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last, my second question, if we can assume that's a one-question question. On the dividend, you kind of probably have some adjustment to make at HCP RemainCo. Tom, we've talked a little bit about this aristocrat status. Do you have any sens
componenttext: Okay. And then last, my second question, if we can assume that's a one-question question. On the dividend, you kind of probably have some adjustment to make at HCP RemainCo. Tom, we've talked a little bit about this aristocrat status. Do you have any sense of the shareholder base that is kind of tied to that and benchmarks to that and would be natural sellers of your stock, assuming you kind of have to cut the dividend?
