componenttext: Yes, I'd just emphasize what I said earlier. I think you can take it to the bank or expect that in the next weeks ahead, we'll have some very definitive news on that and we'll certainly be before the end of the year. So that -- of all of our 5 goals, that's the one that, although we have done a lot of work, we haven't become definitive. But you won't have to wait very long now.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then the dividend payout, the new dividend -- the prorated dividend, can you just talk a little bit about how you guys arrived at that number? How you felt comfortable with the idea that a 74%, 75% FFO payout ratio in '17 was kin
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then the dividend payout, the new dividend -- the prorated dividend, can you just talk a little bit about how you guys arrived at that number? How you felt comfortable with the idea that a 74%, 75% FFO payout ratio in '17 was kind of the appropriate number?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we looked at where we had been historically. And from a FAD payout perspective, and we're not providing FAD per share but let me just take a moment, so we had paid out at about a 85% FAD payout ratio in the past. And as our board reviewed our forward
componenttext: Yes, we looked at where we had been historically. And from a FAD payout perspective, and we're not providing FAD per share but let me just take a moment, so we had paid out at about a 85% FAD payout ratio in the past. And as our board reviewed our forward-looking numbers for this quarter and as we look into 2017 as an initial estimate, it felt comfortable that approximately an 85% payout ratio continued to make sense. So that's how we arrived at the $0.37 a share.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. And then the last question for me is around QCP. Again, since HCP shareholders are still basically holding QCP shares, I don't know if Mark Ordan's on the call, but is there -- I was hoping to get a sense of ultimately what kind of -- QCP is
componenttext: Got it, okay. And then the last question for me is around QCP. Again, since HCP shareholders are still basically holding QCP shares, I don't know if Mark Ordan's on the call, but is there -- I was hoping to get a sense of ultimately what kind of -- QCP is going to be thinking about the dividend and how QCP is going to be thinking about the appropriate rents to ManorCare?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Mike McKee. Mark is not on the call. This is the first day in almost 6 years that I haven't been a fiduciary of a company heavily invested in HCR ManorCare. It's kind of a different experience. I think in a general sense, what Mark has said i
componenttext: Yes. This is Mike McKee. Mark is not on the call. This is the first day in almost 6 years that I haven't been a fiduciary of a company heavily invested in HCR ManorCare. It's kind of a different experience. I think in a general sense, what Mark has said is that he will and his board will be talking about their dividend right away and be announcing where they want to come out. I think he signaled that you should look at it as a modest dividend in the early quarters because they think it's prudent to take some of the rent that they collect and create some cash reserves and balance just to be in a strong a position as they can be. But he totally recognizes he is a REIT and dividends are important. But it will be, I think, a process that occurs not right out of the gate but it will build up as they work through. And I think he's also signaled that he expects to have a pretty active dialogue and possibly negotiation with HCR ManorCare in the early days of his company. So all of that will play in. It will be a time where, I'm sure, as he's already said in his road show, that he can't be pretty definitive at this point. It would be like going into the Super Bowl and giving your opponent your defensive and offensive game plan before you play the game. And so I think you're going to have to be a little patient with some of that. His board, that I mentioned in my earlier remarks, is a very seasoned board. They'll look out for their shareholders very well, a good bit of REIT experience on that board and people that, I think you know and can trust, will be doing the right thing. But we don't know the answer to that. It's up now to their board so we'll kind of have to leave it at that and wish them well.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Mueller of JPMorgan.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Hate to be 1.5 hours into the call and ask something on CapEx but here it goes. The $90 million that you're budgeting for 2017, a couple of questions here. One, can you break that down between the property types? And then also further down the supp, you talked about overall CapEx of about $500 million, can you break that down? How do you get there because it looks like in terms of new development spend, redevelopment, what's left to be spent, including 2016 spend, is maybe $250 million or so, $250 million, $275 million. So what else is in that number?

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hold on, I'm just trying to get to my CapEx schedule, Michael.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm trying to get to my detailed schedule. Bottom line is this. I'll just do it from memory. The recurring CapEx is going to stay fairly stable. You'll probably see just a little bump in that because we've got some lease-up. The first-gen revenue-enh
componenttext: Yes, I'm trying to get to my detailed schedule. Bottom line is this. I'll just do it from memory. The recurring CapEx is going to stay fairly stable. You'll probably see just a little bump in that because we've got some lease-up. The first-gen revenue-enhancing type CapEx, you're going to see decline, from memory, it might have been from about $150 million to probably $80 million because a lot of the Brookdale CapEx expenditures and MOB expenditures that we had planned for 2016 are primarily completed but we still do intend to spend money on some high IRR type expenditures, and we've promised you more analysis around that in the future. And as to development, you'll see that bump up a little bit with The Cove, and we have some additional redevelopment on what we believe to be some quite lucrative redev projects on campus MOB properties that probably are about 30-plus years since they've had redevelopment completed. I have been out, looked at those properties and see some real upside. So when you get into the different buckets, that's what's you're going to see. And I'm just giving it conversationally instead of with details because I couldn't get to my schedule quick enough. But that's what makes up those numbers.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: I was going to say for the $90 million, the $0.20 for the more the FFO type deduct, what are the property type breakdowns? How does that go between senior housing, life science and...

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Now I'm back to my long list of schedules in front of me, and I guess I should have a shorter list so I could get to it quicker. I've got it. Here it is. Hold on. I've got it but you know what, I'll tell you what I prefer to do. Rather than lay out the details of those right now, this was based on our first-look forecast so that we could provide you guys a set of numbers for a jumping off point post-spin. And so I don't want to get quite so specific and I really would rather hold that specific question anyway for our early February call, and we're going to come back with a lot more details. So why don't I punt on that one for now and come back with more detail after we go through our true budgeting process?

componenttext: Okay.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jonathan Hughes of Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jonathan Hughes of Raymond James.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just 2 quick ones. On the Brookdale assets sold, how long have these been underperforming and what was the trajectory there? Was it more rapid deterioration over the past 2 years in the face of the supply and integration challenges? I'm just trying to
componenttext: So just 2 quick ones. On the Brookdale assets sold, how long have these been underperforming and what was the trajectory there? Was it more rapid deterioration over the past 2 years in the face of the supply and integration challenges? I'm just trying to understand if the other 78 could face something besides supply and integration issues.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Justin. As I recall, there's been -- this isn't perfect across every asset, but by and large, there's been decline over the last 2.5, 3 years. There's -- these were properties that came from a variety of different sources. You had some that
componenttext: Sure. This is Justin. As I recall, there's been -- this isn't perfect across every asset, but by and large, there's been decline over the last 2.5, 3 years. There's -- these were properties that came from a variety of different sources. You had some that came legacy Emeritus and came to them from legacy Sunwest, which was a troubled operator that Emeritus was involved with. Probably never did find stabilization, performed pretty well but then went through another merger. So there's been a lot of disruption, I'd say, within that portfolio. Probably is opportunity over time and with a little more focus. But I don't relate those assets to the assets that we've kept. There's a difference in terms of the performance. We've kept more of a stabilized portfolio as characterized, the portfolio we sold as more of a turnaround portfolio.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's really helpful. And then last one. Given that MOBs and life science is now over 40% of HCP 3.0, what's the biggest headwind or potential risk to those asset classes? We know they're incredibly stable but I mean, I'm just trying to get a sense
componenttext: Okay, that's really helpful. And then last one. Given that MOBs and life science is now over 40% of HCP 3.0, what's the biggest headwind or potential risk to those asset classes? We know they're incredibly stable but I mean, I'm just trying to get a sense of any downside risk we may not be thinking of. Is it supply, regulatory risk, election results? Any color there would be great.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the regulatory risk has mitigated quite substantially by getting out of the skilled nursing area and 94% private pay. I think that the primary risk is the one that senior housing is going through now, which is more of a cyclical risk of norm
componenttext: Well, I think the regulatory risk has mitigated quite substantially by getting out of the skilled nursing area and 94% private pay. I think that the primary risk is the one that senior housing is going through now, which is more of a cyclical risk of normal real estate fundamentals of supply and demand. And we're at a pretty high point in terms of life science, but we're very concentrated in the very best markets with the very best properties. So I think that's going to be very stable, and it's going to be -- we're setting some almost kind of really nice precedent with this Cove development that we've got going. I think that you're going to see maybe that as an innovation that we'll want to duplicate, and probably others as well, where you see more of the life science and research properties more on campuses than spread out, where they can get a lot of amenities and synergies. So we feel like we're in a pretty good place here. And I think the simple answer to your question is real estate is always a cyclical business. We can't help that, but that's better than having fundamental problems with an asset class.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: This concludes our question-and-answer session. I would now like to turn the conference back over to Chairman and CEO, Mike McKee, for any closing remarks.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. Let me just conclude by giving some thanks to our Board of Directors who have monitored this whole process throughout. We've had great legal advice from Skadden, Arps, and Paul, Weiss, and their professionalism and wise counsel is ver
componenttext: Thank you very much. Let me just conclude by giving some thanks to our Board of Directors who have monitored this whole process throughout. We've had great legal advice from Skadden, Arps, and Paul, Weiss, and their professionalism and wise counsel is very much appreciated. Our financial advisers at Barclays and Morgan Stanley have done a great job. But I really want to mostly thank our team here at HCP. This is an effort that takes days and nights and weekends of hard and complex work, and they've been unwavering in their focus to complete all these transactions. And I certainly want to thank you on this call for working through these issues with us, for your good questions, your patience and your support. So we hope to see a lot of you at NAREIT in a couple of weeks, and have a good day.

headline: HCP, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
